TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Ray, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, and it is to the background of Labor's television fear campaign in Western Australia. I ask: why should Australian workers believe the scare campaigns, when under your government they are now paying more taxes, despite your promise that there would be no new taxes; they missed out on the l-a-w tax cuts, despite the specific promise of that; pensioners are still paying tax, despite the promise that they would not be taxpayers by 1995; and first home buyers still do not have the use of their superannuation for a home deposit? Why doesn't Labor's litany of lies discount this or any future fear campaigns that you plan to run? Wouldn't your government be doing better by getting on with the job of government rather than running 12 months of fruitless fear campaigns?

—It is the view of this government that the opposition cannot be trusted on industrial relations matters. For the evidence of that, Mr President, you only have to go back to their state counterparts, whom they apparently have no relationship with whatsoever. You only have to look at the campaign promises of Mr Kennett and then see what he translated that to in industrial relations legislation.

PARA.TAB: Mr Kennett went very quiet on industrial relations before the state election in October 1992, and then he introduced some of the most draconian measures seen in this country in the last 20 or 30 years. That included individual work contracts; that included getting rid of holiday loading, et cetera. A lot of these issues eventually got knocked over in the court but, of course, that was by way of the appeal process.

What we saw happen in Victoria was over 370,000 people vote with their feet, leave the state awards and go under the federal award system—the protection of which was approved by this chamber in December 1992. It was a credit to the Senate that it provided these workers with an alternative.

When does the next test come up? The Liberal Party mealy-mouthiness in an election campaign came up in Western Australia. No strong industrial legislation mandate was put to the people of Western Australia when Mr Court was elected. Now we get the first and second wave legislation that senators opposite endorse and embrace.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to them now. They endorse and embrace the Western Australian legislation. Senator Hill asked us, `Well, what about the federal prospects?' Are we entitled to point out that you opposite have not changed your spots on industrial relations? Of course we are entitled to do so. We are even more entitled to do so when you take the craven attitude that, in fact, your policy is in place but, `Oh, no, we can't release it for public purview because we are too scared of government scrutiny.'
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order on the issue of—
—You don't like it. The truth hurts.
—You've got a nerve. With average weekly earnings in this country falling under the Labor Accord, you've got a nerve. On the issue of relevance, the question—
—Why don't you tell the truth for once in your life?

—Us tell the truth! That is the whole point of the question. The point of the question is: after your litany of lies to the taxpayers of Australia, to the pensioners of Australia and to the young people of Australia, why should they believe a word that your government says? Why should the Australian people—
—Order! Senator Hill, are you making a point of order, or are you making a speech?
—Yes. Why should the battlers out there believe a word that you say? Why should they bow to your fear campaign? That is the question I asked, Mr President, and that is the question he should answer.

—On the point of order of relevance: Senator Hill asked why does the government, inasmuch as the party of government, spend some resources on criticising the other side for their industrial relations policy. He calls it a scare campaign. We call it an information campaign. That is the dichotomy of politics, Mr President. But it is absolutely relevant to point out the track record of the Liberal Party at two state levels to show that they will do exactly the same thing at a federal level. Therein lies the relevance of what I am saying.
—Order! The question was broad enough to demand a fairly broad answer, I have to say. I believe it is relevant.

—The reason Senator Hill and the opposition try to shout me down is that every time we make the point of how their credibility goes in the question of industrial relations, Mr Robb, their spokesman says, `Ah yes, we've done all the policy work.' Where is it? What is so horrendous that you have to hide it?

PARA.TAB: The one area where Mr Howard has never ever changed his attitude is industrial relations. As he said to a business gathering just a few weeks ago, he will have a mandate on industrial relations because he has not changed on this subject. We are entitled to say you have not changed on this subject.

We are facing a situation where the number of work days lost is at its lowest level in 55 years. A lot of that is to do with the accord process and the policies of this government that have led to the social cohesion to bring about that result. Those opposite, simply through their old class prejudices, seek to disrupt that. They seek to crawl to a constituency that does not even belong to them. The employers do not even believe them on this! They are disgusted at the attitude of those opposite trying to stir up the industrial relations pot again to return to the 1960s and 1950s, which these people opposite would like to do.
So don't you lecture us about scare campaigns, Senator Hill. You produce your policy. You have a supplementary question, you put your policy on the table and we will debate it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade.
—You didn't write it though, sport.
—This is a great question and if you shut up, you will hear the answer.
—Order!

—The launch last week of the Australian Food Council as the industry's peak representative body highlighted the opportunities and constraints facing Australia's food industry, particularly in the east-Asian region. What barriers exist in the region which affect the industry's capacity to realise its enormous growth potential and what is the government doing to assist industry overcome these?

—I thank Senator Forshaw for the question because it is of direct relevance to a lot of workers in New South Wales and it is appropriate that he should raise it. Both I and my colleagues Senator Bob Collins and Senator Cook had the great pleasure of being involved last week with the launch of the Australian Food Council. We were very pleased about that because it provides the government with an excellent forum in which to discuss strategies and priorities in a very important area of trade growth. The council sets a very high priority on the important issue of market access, of how we can deliver more and greater market access outcomes for processed food. We are pleased to work with them on this as they have said they are looking forward to doing with us. We really have a very close match between the priorities of this industry group and the government in reducing tariffs, eliminating non-tariff barriers and getting unreasonable quarantine barriers out of the way of our processed food sector in the region.

PARA.TAB: It is very welcome to the government—particularly to me as trade minister and, I know, to my colleagues—that this industry is part of Australia's largest manufacturing sector, which is becoming increasingly export oriented with exports growing by more than 45 per cent since the beginning of the decade. Those exports are now valued at more than $12 billion, an increase of $3 1/2 billion over the last four years—almost $1 billion a year. It is particularly valuable that the greatest increase in exports has been in the sector of the highly processed foods where the highest value is added. This is where the greatest value therefore is being contributed to the Australian economy and it is very much part of the focus on our east-Asian region.

Ten of our 15 largest markets for processed food are situated in east Asia. As incomes rise, we can expect to see an increase in the quantity of food being consumed and a shift towards more processed food, which we are particularly well placed to provide. Therefore, it is a sector of increased significance to Australia.

My department's report entitled Subsistence to supermarket: food and agricultural transformation in South-East Asia, which was released last year, forecast that the south-east Asian market for food and agricultural products could reach about $77 billion by 2010. By merely retaining our market share, the Australian food industry could increase its exports to South-East Asia alone by almost $5 billion over the 20 years to 2010. But maintaining our market share is not going to be an easy task. It sounds easy, but the market place is getting much more competitive. More and more people are coming into the market. Of course, as new participants come into the market, it gets harder. But our market share as against all the other non-south-east Asian players in this market is going up, and we need to continue to focus on that. It is not going to be easy to maintain our market share but it is very important that we do.

There are great opportunities out there but there are also great obstacles, as Senator Forshaw has outlined. The CEDA report highlighted those obstacles. We are trying through APEC and through our bilateral activities to focus on them. For example, we are hoping in the very short term to get a bit of a breakthrough in relation to New Zealand to keep open the market for our highly processed grain and our value added products which will be of value of Australia's manufacturers. To the members of the Australian Food Council, we welcome its formation and we look forward to working with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Just last week the President of the Master Builders Association warned that the Accord is failing in maintaining its objective of having two to three per cent inflation. He also accused your government's industrial relations policies of contributing to the boom-bust cycle in the building and construction industry because of the lack of a checks and balances framework in the industry. Isn't it the case that the Accord is failing in its major objectives of low inflation and protection of building construction workers' jobs, which the president made note of in his speech? Also, why should Australian workers believe any claims your government is making about the success of the Accord on wages, job security and containment of the boom-bust economic cycle?

—On the last point, because they are true—that is why they should believe them, and the statistics establish that. I am surprised that you should raise that question. If we do a comparison of real wage growth under our government compared with real wage growth under the Fraser government when Mr Howard was Treasurer, real wage growth faltered under you but rose under us. That is what the statistics show—that is why people believe it. They know it to be a fact—that is why they believe it. They can jingle the extra coins in their pocket—that is why they believe it. On the question of the Accord, the Accord has served the Australian community very well over the nearly 13 years of this government. It has managed to do this: it has managed to moderate growth in wages, enabled the government to trade that off against tax cuts and enabled the government to grow the social wage so that the living standards of ordinary Australians improve. At the end of the day, if you hark back to the bad old days of the Fraser government we were all too familiar with high wage increases eroded by high inflation.

PARA.TAB: We have broken the back of the inflation stick, as you know, Senator Crane. The levels of inflation that Australia has now are much much lower than what we were used to under the Fraser government. I think when Mr Fraser went out of power inflation was about 11.3 per cent. We are talking about keeping inflation in the range of two to three per cent. Your question sought to criticise me as to whether or not inflation is remaining in that range of two to three per cent. I remind you that when your party was last in government it was about 11.3 per cent. So let us get this thing in proportion. Essentially, it is living standards not high wages being eroded by high inflation. We have turned that around with the Accord.

Moreover, we have done it on a cooperative basis. We have worked with the unions and employers; and generated a cooperative industrial relations culture in Australian work places. The only work places in Australia where that is being upset are where there are state liberal governments introducing draconian industrial legislation. It brings back the bad old days of confrontation.

We are, I think, the only government in the world that has the privilege of saying honestly and openly that the union movement of this country has endorsed the Reserve Bank's inflation target. Accord mark 8 commits the Australian Council of Trade Unions to deliver a wages outcome which will keep inflation in the range of two to three per cent. No-one else in the world that I am aware of has got that commitment. The unions in this country have a track record of sticking to and delivering on their promises—and I expect them to deliver on this.

Let us look at the remarks just last week of the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Fraser. While making an observation about the commitment, he too—from his remarks—expects them to deliver on that. That would be good news for Australia. Inflation trips around a bit as wage settlements come through. I suppose we will hear a bit this week about that from the commentators. But the outcome of two to three per cent is what is promised. While the index might oscillate a little, it is the outcome at the end of the day that counts, not the oscillations on the road to that outcome. As far as the boom-bust cycle in the building industry is concerned, I have been associated with the building industry in Australia for many years and it leaves—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In your answer, Minister, you said it was state governments which were providing the provocative, bad industrial systems. If that is the case, can you explain to us, as the ABS statistics show, why under the WA Lawrence Labor government for the year ending June 1991 there were 313 working days lost per thousand employees? That compares with the national figure of 254. We find that in the first full year of the Court government the number of working days lost under the same measure of per thousand employees was 46 at the state level compared with 82 at the federal level. If the state system is so bad, can you also explain to us why the recent minimum wage increase under the WA system was $16, which is double the $8 the Accord will produce under the federal system for those unfortunate enough to be the lowest paid employees. Isn't what you have just said and the answer you have just given further evidence of the litany of lies that your government is peddling at the current time?

—What a joke! I have eight questions and one minute to answer the lot. Let me take them as a job lot. The reason why those figures are able to be quoted is that during the period of the Lawrence government the level of industrial disputation in Western Australia was coming down from the very high levels of the former Court government. It continued on its pathway down during the early stages of the Dick Court government. But who stirred up the hornet's nest? Look at the figures now. We had most workers in Western Australia on strike, voluntarily removing themselves from their place of employment, to protest against that government's legislation. So in the face of that irrefutable fact, I do not know how you can contend that Liberal governments are better at industrial relations than are Labor governments. The reason why industrial disputes in Australia have fallen is that we have created the right climate of cooperation. We have turned our backs on the confrontation that marks your governments. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and it relates to the announcement on Friday by the Queensland and Commonwealth governments of a $16 million package to protect the mahogany glider and other flora and fauna along the Queensland coastline. I ask the minister to outline to the Senate how this welcome package will protect these species.

—It is true that the Queensland and Commonwealth governments have put in place a sugar coast environment rescue package. Each government will be contributing $8 million to that package over three years. The $16 million rescue package will greatly benefit a number of threatened species. One of the most important of these, and certainly one which has received a lot of recent publicity, is the mahogany glider. Until 1989, the mahogany glider was thought to be extinct. This package will protect the habitat which is critical to the survival of the glider. It will ensure that habitat loss is minimised and that corridors between the various colonies are protected.

PARA.TAB: I do not think the significance of this package should be underestimated. I notice that its importance has been recognised in Saturday's Townsville Bulletin by the man who rediscovered the species in 1989, Steve van Dyck. Mr van Dyck is right to be very enthusiastic about the package. The reality is that, if we did not do this—the buy-back, the conservation plan and the declaration of critical habitat under the Queensland act—there would be a real risk that the glider and other species, such as the southern cassowary, would become extinct.

Development has led to incredible pressures on the habitats of these endangered and threatened species. This package will enable the Queensland government to buy back more than 38,000 hectares along the Queensland coastline. Most of the crucial mahogany glider habitat areas between the Sunshine Coast and Cairns will now be bought back and added to existing national parks. Voluntary conservation agreements will be introduced on the remaining crucial habitat areas. Land holders will be offered half a million dollars worth of financial incentives to undertake these agreements.

The Queensland government has also announced that it will introduce a conservation plan for the mahogany glider under its Nature Conservation Act. This will limit activities threatening to the existence of gliders while allowing for the continuation of existing and future uses which are compatible to the conservation of the gliders.

The Queensland Minister for Environment and Heritage, Tom Barton, and I look forward to the support of the sugar industry on the implementation of this package. I am delighted that the canegrowers have already expressed strong support for the package in a letter to the Prime Minister. This package really reflects the federal government's ongoing commitment to protecting endangered species. More broadly, again, it really reinforces this government's commitment to protecting the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In June 1992, in my minority report to the Senate superannuation committee, I called for a portion of superannuation to be invested in Australian venture capital projects with export potential, which I see the Prime Minister now expressing some interest in. Why did not the government think this was an important issue in 1993-94, when unemployment was at 10 per cent and domestic investment was low? Why did the government not think this was important before the 1995 budget announcement to introduce the employee co-contribution, which will give the funds another $10 billion a year? Does it take an attack by the fund managers on one of the Prime Minister's dinner partners to get some action?

—I will ignore the last comment as a cheap shot, because, frankly, that is what it is. I took it that you used a cheap analogy in order to illustrate your point. Let me go to the point so that I can keep away from the cheapness of that shot and concentrate on the substance of the issue.

PARA.TAB: From this question, the impartial listener or viewer would think that we are not concerned about this issue or have just lately become concerned about it. That is not true. We have been concerned about it all the way along. The difference is that we have a different way of approaching the solution to it than you have. The difference between us is that you would intervene and direct, whereas we would encourage the market to work more efficiently. It is for the community to judge which is the most important path here.

One has to remember that superannuation funds are contributions made by and on behalf of workers in Australia in order to provide for their retirement. The management of those funds is a very serious matter, in order to ensure that when those workers retire they can retire in a dignified way and with an income for which they have invested and provided.

It is a measure of this government that we introduced that on a fair basis. Prior to our period in government superannuation applied only to a select group of white collar workers and senior company executives. Now it applies to just about everyone in Australia, including the lowliest blue-collar worker to the highest executive as well. Everyone has the right to superannuation. That is something that the opposition have fought against.

Rather than direct the people who have entrusted in them the management of those funds, we have always believed that you give that responsibility to the elected appointees of the beneficiaries to manage that fund so that you do not have government directing, you have the elected trustees of the funds managing those funds.

Secondly, we have provided that the legislation under which we have done this allows those trustees to have a balanced portfolio of investments. That is a way of saying that a balanced portfolio would be a portfolio in which there was provision of funds for venture capital and there was provision of funds for developmental capital, as well as some funds in long-term maturities which would ensure that the return to the overall fund was balanced.

I know that the Prime Minister has been saying in recent days that he is unhappy with the way in which some of those funds have addressed that balance. He is not alone in that. There is quite considerable objective support for his concern. For example, the National Investment Council study `Financing Growth' noted that the proportion of investment in superannuation funds in venture development capital seems to be only about half the 3.5 per cent level of the United States; that is, we do not manage our venture and developmental capital investments as well as they do in the United States.

This is not necessarily a reason to direct it. It is certainly a reason to provide, as we did recently, that there should be reporting for five-year horizons of investment in superannuation funds. It is certainly a reason to encourage better training, understanding and education of trustees so that they better understand risk and are better able to make those assessments, and it is a reason for a number of those other things. But if the dividing point comes down to whether we direct or whether we encourage the market to work, I guess you are among the interventionists; we are among those encouraging the market to work. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to argue with me that the market has worked? Don't you think the Prime Minister's comments about donkeys actually suggest that the all-knowing market has got it wrong yet again? Can you give the Senate any assurance that the government will release a position on this issue before the Senate has to vote on the super co-contribution?
—What I have said is that our preference is to encourage the market to work and take steps to ensure the market works in a far more balanced way.
—How?

—I have enumerated those in my earlier answer. The Prime Minister's criticisms show that we are not satisfied that it is working in a balanced way. We do think that more attention could be paid by trustees. I endorse him absolutely, because that is the fact.

PARA.TAB: As to the second part of that question: I am not sure what the timetabling is. If you will allow me, I will take that on notice and get an answer to you at the first available opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Crowley, the Minister for Family Services. I draw the minister's attention to a letter in the Financial Review today headed `Income-splitting a big help for families'. Are the proponents of income splitting correct in saying it would help families? Is the government giving any consideration to introducing this system of taxation?

—I did have the letter by Susan Bastick of the Australian Family Association drawn to my attention today. I have to say that that letter by Mrs Bastick draws very considerably on the comments by the Leader of the Opposition and his colleagues in the Lyons forum. Mr Howard in particular and the Lyons forum in one of its recommendations have come out as very strong supporters of income splitting. They actually want to attack this government's targeted payments, for example, those to single mothers, and at the same time they want to argue for the very regressive program of income splitting—and regressive and very expensive it is.

PARA.TAB: According to the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling, income splitting would cost $3.9 billion. What is more than that, about 70 per cent of income earners would be net losers; 95 per cent of the benefits would go to the top 50 per cent of incomes and 39 per cent of the benefits would go to the top 20 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's absolutely meaningless unless you define the terms.

—It is not meaningless at all. It is actually about a direct shift. If you should go the income splitting way, it would be a direct transference of money from low income families to high income families, Senator. This is very clear.

PARA.TAB: Professor Patricia Apps from Sydney University told a recent conference that income splitting was `regressive, inefficient, anti-saving and wouldn't even help families with children'. You would have to say that income splitting is not a policy that this government is interested in adopting at all. We know full well that it is very regressive, that it would only benefit those at the top end and that it would be very disadvantaging for families at the lower end of the scale.

This government's policies are very clear. We strongly support families. We support families through family income payments, basic family payments and additional family payments. We support families through things like Medicare. We certainly have supported families through our education policies. What, after all, do families say they most want assistance with?
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on both sides. There are some people interested in this answer.
—Thank you very much, Mr President.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Where are they?

TALK.START.PARA: —They are listening, senators. They are listening to the opposition's policies about income splitting and they know that they are very bad policies. They know that you want to argue for them and so does Mr Howard. They need to know and be assured that this government's policies have targeted payments of basic family payment, additional family payment, Medicare and introduced the maternity allowance. Those are the sorts of payments that are targeted to families at the lower income scale that will be of great benefit to Australian families. They are best illustrated with our child-care policies. Through child-care assistance, Senator Hill, and through the child-care cash rebate we are assisting families.

PARA.TAB: Income splitting would be an absolute devastation for families. It would distribute to the top end, it would take away from the bottom end, and it would cost—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not necessarily.

—If it is not necessarily so, Senator Hill, what work have you done on this that you are not telling us? What model of income splitting is it that you have not told us yet? When are you going to come clear on your income splitting policy? Let us know. Why don't you tell us, Senator, and have a proper debate about it?

—On a point of order, Mr President: you might direct Minister Crowley. The question related to a letter in the Financial Review today from a Mrs Bastick. I do not think that has any relationship to the matter she is now pursuing in her answer.
—I think you should get back to the point of the answer, if you have not completed it already, Senator.

—The point of the answer in summary is that the government is not at all persuaded to income splitting; the opposition is. As Senator Hill indicates, quite clearly they are doing a lot of work on it, because he is talking about what sort of income splitting. So when you come clear and tell us your policies—if you have got any, Senator—we can have a proper debate. In the meantime, the argument about income splitting stands. (Time expired)

I refer to yesterday's damning comments by the Executive Director of the Australian Investment Managers Association, Mr Ian Matheson, who described the Prime Minister's intervention in the Coles Myer affair as extraordinary and unwarranted, and alleged that Mr Keating and Mr Kelty were more interested in helping their business mates than anything else. Isn't it a fact that Mr Keating's intervention at such a decisive stage in the institution's battle to bring about comprehensive reforms in the corporate governance of Coles Myer has resulted in a compromise well short of the institution's preferred position and one which is certainly not in accordance with the wishes of the shareholders? Why is Mr Keating not prepared to argue the case for improved standards of corporate governance? Is it because he does not believe in ethical standards, or does he simply now instinctively identify with the big end of town rather than with the battlers from Bankstown?

—As I pointed out in my interjection before, Mr President, Senator Alston, Senator Kemp and company had a big $1,000 fund-raiser in Melbourne with about 380 guests. They raised $300,000. And they are talking about the battlers from the small end of town! This is the Liberal Party of Victoria that is doing deals with Walker and Williams every day of the week. PARA.TAB: Senator Alston asked about the Prime Minister's intervention. That came in two forms, I would have thought. One was to say, just in his view, that some of the plans for a rationalisation in Coles Myer were sensible. But it seems to me that both sides of the corporate argument there seem to agree with that. As for those comments in relation to bringing about a compromise on the selection of a new board, who knows? I understand it is to be announced in the next day or two who in fact will constitute the new board of Coles Myer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't mention them.
—No, but I did, Senator, and I intend to.

—On a point of order, Mr President: he is just conceding that his answer is irrelevant. He admitted that I did not ask him anything about it, but he is now choosing to go on to talk about something that interests him. That is not relevant.
—There is no point of order.

—The relevance, whether you asked it or not, Senator Alston, is as to the Prime Minister's attitude to this particular set of circumstances. One of the circumstances—because you asked the question about institutional funds—was his view that the institutions are rather dull and unimaginative in the degree of investments they make, especially in the innovative area.

PARA.TAB: The absolute palpable nonsense of Senator Alston's question goes to the point that the Prime Minister has intervened to support one side or the other. This has been a contentious public matter. All he has sought to do is two things: firstly, criticise some of the fund managers for their lack of innovation—a thing that I think many people in this chamber would agree with; and, secondly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Donkeys—he called them donkeys.

—No, not necessarily in terms of the total description but in terms of the overall analysis. The second one was to put his own view that maybe Coles Myer would operate more effectively if broken up into units. I don't make a comment on that; he did.

—On a point of order, Mr President. This is very sad. I would have thought, Mr President, you are in a perfect position to judge whether Senator Ray has completely missed the point or not. I did not ask him anything about the investment decisions of Coles Myer or the institutions; I did not ask him anything about donkeys; I simply asked about the intervention at a critical stage in relation to the compromise on the board—nothing to do with any of those matters that have been raised. I am sure you are not going to do anything about it. I simply would invite you, however, to point out to Senator Ray that he ought to listen to the question and not simply read the brief.

—It was not only wide ranging, Mr President, but what Senator Alston always does in here is dredge up every allegation and accept it as fact. Any allegation, any polemic or assertion, is taken by poor old simplistic Senator Alston as an absolute fact. The Prime Minister was asked, either by way of press or in question time, about attitudes or allusions on this and he gave a view. It was not one that he necessarily volunteered; it was one in terms of answering others.
—He stopped the corporate restructure.

—Senator Alston makes the allegation by way of interjection that the Prime Minister—he alone—stopped the thing. I would have thought one of the impediments to this is the diffused nature of the shareholders. They get their say. The shareholders will have their say, I think on 18 November—I am not sure but around about then. They will get their say on who they want to elect to the board, and they can elect whoever they like to the board. Whether they take a how-to-vote card off the Prime Minister, Mr Solomon Lew or Mr Nick Greiner is their business.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to hearings in the International Court of Justice on the legality of the use, or threat of use, of nuclear weapons and, in particular, to the Australian submission to the forthcoming oral hearings on the two advisory opinions that the court has received on the subject. I ask: can the minister outline the submission to be put by the Australian government at those hearings, and can he indicate who will be representing Australia at the International Court of Justice? Given that Japan has included the mayors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki on its delegation to highlight the impact of the use of nuclear weapons, did Australia give consideration to including representatives on our delegation of the Aboriginal people in this country who have suffered from the effects of nuclear testing? If not, why not?

—Australia will make an oral submission in the forthcoming hearings by the International Court of Justice on the legality of the use or threat of nuclear weapons. The oral submission will make clear our general position on nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation and our strong opposition to nuclear testing. We will clearly express our condemnation of the resumption of French nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

PARA.TAB: The government is committed to the eventual elimination of nuclear weapons and therefore we sympathise with those who seek an advisory opinion from the ICJ. But there are a number of difficult issues to be addressed in making a case to the court in favour of an advisory opinion which would in fact bring closer the goal of eliminating nuclear weapons. Once you invite the court to deliver such an opinion you must accept the possibility that there might be a finding that the use or threat of nuclear weapons might, in some circumstances, be legal. If you invite an opinion you have to accept the possibility that it might not be the opinion you want. That would be a serious setback to the current encouraging trends in nuclear disarmament negotiations and achievements. TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday I was asked by Senator Alston to give a considered response on the question of relevance. The relevance of answers was considered by the Procedure Committee in its second report of 1994, presented in November 1994. The committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that, in answering a question, a minister must be relevant to the question. It is for the President to make a judgment whether an answer is relevant to a question. If the answer is not relevant, the President requires the minister to be relevant.

The committee considered whether reflections on the questioner could be relevant and concluded, `as with all questions of relevance, this must be left to the judgment of the chair'. In spite of this very clear statement, there has continued to be some disputation about the relevance of answers and my rulings on points of order relating to relevance.

PARA.TAB: As my very first predecessor, President Baker, ruled in 1904, relevance means relevance to the subject matter under consideration. A speech, amendment or answer is relevant to a motion, bill or question if it deals with the same subject matter. Thus, if a question concerns the state of the economy, a minister's answer is relevant if it refers to the state of the economy.

I think that there is a tendency to confuse relevance and responsiveness. An answer can be relevant to a question—that is, it can deal with the same subject matter—without necessarily being responsive to the question. If a question asks whether the level of foreign debt is undermining the economy and a minister answers that the economy is sound because of factors that outweigh the foreign debt, the minister's answer is clearly relevant in so far as it deals with the same subject matter—the state of the economy—although the answer may not be responsive in so far as it is not confined to the effect of foreign debt on the economy.

It appears also not to be fully appreciated that, if a subject is introduced into a question, a minister is entitled to refer to that subject in the answer. If a question asks whether the level of foreign debt is indicative of the failure of government's policies, the minister is entitled to refer to the government's policies and their perceived successes.

If a question contains a political barb, a minister is entitled, while remaining relevant, to return political barbs. If a questioner alleges that the government is seeking to conceal the effects of its policies, the subject of concealment having been introduced, a minister is entitled to claim, without devoting the whole answer to the matter, that it is not the government but the opposition which is in the business of concealment.

If senators require that ministers confine themselves in their answers strictly to a defined subject, the question itself must be confined to that defined subject. Although interjections are disorderly, they are tolerated to a certain extent as part of the interchange of debate. If an interjection is made by the questioner or the questioner's party during an answer and the chair allows the interjection, it cannot be expected that the minister will be restrained from responding to the interjection and any subject matter that may be introduced by the interjection. If a questioner asks about foreign debt, and during the answer the questioner by interjection refers to the level of interest rates, it can only be expected that the minister will refer to interest rates in the answer.

I have examined the rulings of my recent predecessors on relevance, and I do not consider that they applied the relevance rule significantly more strictly than I have. I will continue to exercise the judgment of the chair as to whether answers are relevant to questions, and in so doing I will not restrain ministers from referring to any elements of a question which the questioner has seen fit to include.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the clear connection, which the opposition seems incapable of drawing, between innovation and science and the things which support innovation and science. —Why do you flog them to death then?

SPEECH.PARA: VARIATION TO THE 1995 SPRING LEGISLATION PROGRAM
AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
STATEMENT OF REASONS
Purpose of the proposed amendments

1. The main purpose of the proposed Bill is to clarify the power of the Commissioner to terminate the appointment of police and staff members of the members of the Australian Federal Police (AFP). This power is provided for at section 26E of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 (the AFP Act).

2. The Commissioner's power to terminate appointments is part of the special employment scheme for the AFP which was introduced in 1990. It is a specific anti-corruption measure intended to reduce the dangers of entrenched corruption such as has been uncovered at various times in other police forces.

3. The main difficulty is that section 26E, as it presently stands, contains restrictions which prevent the Commissioner from dealing with the kinds of situations which the power was intended to cover. Subsection 26E(3) currently prohibits the Commissioner from terminating an appointment solely because of an act or omission which has been, or could be, the subject of a charge under AFP (Discipline) Regulations or because of a court conviction for a criminal offence. The Commissioner's difficulties are compounded when lengthy criminal or disciplinary processes have commenced, or are in prospect, with uncertain outcomes, and the Commissioner has already had reasonable cause to have lost confidence in a member's or staff member's suitability for continued employment. The Bill will omit subsection 26E(3).

4. The Bill will also allow AFP appointees, in most circumstances, to access the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. Currently AFP appointees are excluded from these provisions by Industrial Relations Regulations. However, there will be an exception where an appointment is terminated because the Commissioner is satisfied that continued retention of the individual would be immediately harmful to the integrity, reputation and status of the AFP. In those exceptional circumstances, the Commissioner's decision will continue to be excluded from the unfair dismissal provisions but the individual will retain a right to seek judicial review of the decision and an entitlement to compensation.

Each of the Bills proposes to incorporate into legislation outstanding Customs or Excise Tariff proposals, including those which implemented this year's Budget changes to the duty rates on tobacco products and light fuel oil.

Under the respective sections of the Customs Act 1901 and Excise Act 1901 (Sections 226 and 114 refer), tariff proposals are required to be incorporated into legislation within 12 months of their tabling in the Parliament, or the close of the session of Parliament in which the proposals were introduced, whichever first happens. If this does not occur, the proposals are of no effect, and the duty collected under them is subject to return.

Parliamentary consideration of the Bills this Sittings is necessary because of the substantial amount of duty which has been collected under the proposals to date, and which could be put at risk if incorporation is not to proceed. If the incorporation into legislation is deferred until next year due to the postponement of the debate on the relevant Tariff Amendment Bills, the amount of duty which will have been collected could be in excess of $100 million.
CUSTOMS TARIFF BILL 1995
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN
SPRING SITTINGS

The proposed Customs Tariff Bill 1995 will give effect to the extensive classification changes in the Harmonised Commodity Description and Coding System of the World Customs Organisation. The changes affect 1/3 of the current Customs Tariff Act 1987, and this Bill will effectively introduce a new Tariff Bill in much the same way as the current 1987 Tariff replaced the 1982 Tariff following a similar international harmonisation exercise.

Parliamentary consideration of the Bill this Sittings is necessary primarily because of the 6 month lead time which this legislation requires before its commencement. The World Customs Organisation, of which Australia is an active member, is committed to a 1996 commencement of the new harmonised description and classification system. Australia has indicated its preparedness to have the new system in by 1 July 1996.

To accommodate that mid-year commencement, the Bill will need to be in place by at least 1 January 1996. Not only will the importing community require this lead time to make the necessary computer software and documentary changes resulting from the Bill but in addition, there is a need to check and revalidate the 120,000 tariff advices which importers hold on the tariff classification of goods, together with the checking and re-execution of the 10,000 Tariff Concession Orders currently on hand to allow the duty free entry of goods.

Working title of the bill:Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill No. 1 1995.
Purpose of bill:
The Bill will make miscellaneous amendments to superannuation legislation. The main purposes being to:

PARA.TAB: improve and refine the complaints handling system within the superannuation industry; and
ensure no legislative gaps arise as a result of the expiry of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner's ability to issue temporary modification declarations; and
ensure the ISC has sufficient supervisory powers to protect members.

SPEECH.PARA: Reasons for seeking introduction and passage of the bill in the 1995 Spring Sittings

PARA.TAB: The Bill will contain provisions to amend the jurisdiction of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal so as to enable it to deal more efficiently and directly with complaints regarding life office superannuation products and medical evidence complaints involving life office decisions. The Government has made a commitment that the Tribunal will be able to deal effectively and efficiently with medical evidence complaints from 1 November 1995 and wishes to honour its commitment by ensuring that the necessary amendments to enable the Tribunal to deal with such complaints in an effective and efficient manner are in place by that date;

The bill will also `transfer' a number of temporary modification declarations made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner under Part 29 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (the SIS Act) into the actual body of the SIS Act itself. The SIS Act provides that these temporary declarations (which in effect represent part of the Act) will cease to have effect from 30 June 1996. Unless legislation to replace these declarations is included in the SIS Act well in advance of this date then serious disruption could be caused to significant parts of the superannuation industry. For example, many small (less than 5 member) funds would suddenly, and inappropriately, be classified as `public offer funds' and the trustee of such funds (which is often `mum or dad') would need to become a corporate trustee, be approved by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and meet stringent financial backing requirements (such as having $5 million in net tangible assets). It is considered essential that these amendments are passed in the Spring Sittings to avoid problems of this sort emerging and to provide the necessary comfort to industry well in advance of the 30 June 1996 cut off date. This will ensure industry does not (to the likely detriment of members) begin rearranging its affairs because of a belief that the amendments will not be in place by 30 June 1996.

The remaining amendments in the Bill are also time critical if the supervisory system is to be sufficiently strong to protect members. For example, included in these amendments are measures to address two significant gaps which have been found in the ISC's supervisory powers:

TAB.TAB: the ISC needs the power to apply to a court for appointment of a receiver where this is necessary to protect members; and
the ISC needs the power to require external auditors to check on fund compliance with the requirements of the SIS legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice and at the request of the Leader of the Australian Democrats in the Senate, Senator Kernot, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Kernot moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to General Business notice of motion no. 1794 standing in the name of Senator Spindler for this day, relating to the establishment of an inquiry into the bombing of the Sydney Hilton Hotel.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, it is urgent that this matter be debated by the Senate today because there are indications that, once again, it will be swept under the carpet. Twice the New South Wales parliament voted unanimously to call for a joint federal-state inquiry into this matter: once on 9 December 1991, and again on 21 September 1995. In other words, the ALP in opposition and in government voted for this particular motion, and the coalition in opposition and in government voted for this particular motion.

PARA.TAB: Yet there are signs that the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) will not back this particular motion that I wish to move today—that the federal government take part in a joint New South Wales-federal government inquiry. There are signs—and I have had indications—that the coalition will go to water as well, despite the fact that they have in New South Wales voted twice for a similar resolution.

In his letter to me dated 18 September 1995, the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, said that Commonwealth police shared responsibility for the personal protection of delegates, when outside the conference venue, jointly with the New South Wales police. But he went on to say that it was the New South Wales police that had responsibility for security outside the Hilton Hotel, including in George Street.

The Attorney-General uses that as one of the main points for saying that the Australian government need not and should not be involved in an inquiry. It is therefore on the cards that the government will once again back off. The urgency of this particular matter to be debated by the Senate today, however, is supported by the fact that we now have two additional items of information.

In the report of the outgoing Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, Mr Roger Holdich, we are told that not one but two ASIO agents were inside the Ananda Marga. And, further, that ASIO had withheld from the courts information obtained from both these agents which would have affected these judicial proceedings. Further, we are told—and it is reported in an article in the Age newspaper—that a scientist had been asked by ASIO to prepare two bombs.

The Age further reports—and the date of that article is 27 July 1995 by Sheena McLean—that two politicians, the federal Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Frank Walker, and a former Labor state MP, Mr George Petersen, say that the scientist came forward to reveal that he had been asked to make two bombs. The bombs were to contain live explosives but the detonator mechanisms were to be benign.

Four years ago, Mr Walker disclosed that he had met the scientist and he stands by that report. Yet we are told by the Attorney-General that this is not a matter concerning ASIO or the Commonwealth government. But it is a matter that does concern a number of Australian people. Three people were killed by the explosion. Mr Griffiths, one of eight survivors, is partially deaf in both ears, diabetic, agoraphobic and suffers panic attacks that leave him exhausted. The Australian Democrats believe that this is a matter that must be investigated by the federal government. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the suspension of standing orders. We do not believe that anything has been put forward to us by Senator Spindler in his just concluded speech, or any other material, that would warrant a suspension of standing orders to bring this matter on as a matter of urgency.

PARA.TAB: One should point out, of course, that this matter has been going on in one form or another since 1978. It is 17 years since the tragic incident took place. There have been innumerable inquiries at the New South Wales state government level, and people have been gaoled and then released. I do not profess to know all the ins and outs of all of those details. One has to be a considerable expert in the so-called Hilton case to follow it all. But we do not believe this motion has to come on now after a suspension of standing orders.

Any suggestion that this government is trying to hide any background on this because it could be embarrassing just does not stand up, as we were not the government at the time. When this whole episode took place way back in 1978, the Fraser coalition government was in office. So there would be nothing embarrassing to this government if any event did involve any federal government agency. It was clearly not of this government's making.

So far not enough evidence has been put forward to warrant us holding a royal commission—a very expensive royal commission. If such issues do exist, we believe that the New South Wales government, as the relevant authority, would be willing to have its own royal commission. So far, I see that they are apparently not willing to do so. We do not believe that there is enough evidence and I believe that the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) in the letter to you, Senator Spindler, recently made that point.

We have all seen royal commissions used in recent times for particular political purposes but at great expense to the taxpayer. The Attorney-General's view is that until further evidence is put forward to warrant the expense of a royal commission, which just by the very fact of calling one would cost several million dollars—and that evidence has so far not been produced—we believe it is a matter for the New South Wales government.

Above all, we are now debating at the moment not the merits of the Hilton case at all, but the issue of whether there should be a suspension of standing orders. We do not believe that this issue warrants the urgency of the suspension of standing orders and, therefore, we will oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —For very much similar reasons to those outlined by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), the coalition will support the government in opposing the Australian Democrats motion to suspend standing orders to ensure that this matter is debated here and now. I do not say at all that this is not an important matter. The integrity of your judicial system and your law enforcement agencies, including ASIO, is an essential element of a properly functioning, free, democratic society.

PARA.TAB: When any of these agencies are put under threat, or a cloud is put over their name, there is obviously a great desire by those people who see the integral part that they played cleared up. I do not take Senator Spindler's suggestion that the matter be debated now as an attempt to get stuck into ASIO; but, rather, as an attempt to clear ASIO of these allegations that are hanging around. But I have some sympathy with the view put forward by the minister that there perhaps is not sufficient evidence at the moment.

I, like Senator Spindler, unless he has had information made available to him that has not been made available to me, am not in possession of some information that the government is clearly in possession of. But as I indicated to Senator Spindler recently, in this pre-election environment something tells me down to my bones that if there was something in there that could smear a past Liberal government, this government would have dug it out and rushed off to have a royal commission as quick as it could. I just somehow feel that.

Forgive me for the cynicism with which I approach this matter. But I look across on the other side and think, if you could pin this on a law enforcement agency when there was a Liberal government, you would be doing it. Maybe my cynicism is misplaced, I don't know; I certainly hope not. The thought did occur to me, though, when the minister was raising exactly the same point in his remarks, that if the subsequent inquiries—and I do not have the dates of those fixed in my mind—flowed over into a Labor government—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't think they would have been yes-ministered by ASIO, perhaps?

—That may be a point. But if that is the case, I am not sure that you will ever get to the bottom of the matter—ever. And you do have to consider the extent to which you allocate taxpayers' money to express your desire to get to the bottom of it. There has to be a point at which you say, `Not only does this express my desire to get to the bottom of it, but I actually think we are effectively spending taxpayers' money.' We can all come in here and express the desire that this matter should have already been resolved and should not be hanging around as one of the myths and that it should be removed off the political horizon. We can all want that in our heart of hearts, and our minds might tell us it is the best thing to do. But, as the minister rightly says, a royal commission will cost millions of dollars.

PARA.TAB: Unless you have at the commencement of that commission a genuine view that you will resolve the matter, all you will be doing is spending more taxpayers' money and adding to the consternation in the community about the matter. The minister will probably say it is misplaced confidence, but I do believe that this side of politics will win the next election. At that point, if I am offered the job that I have now in a shadow capacity, I may be in a better position to know. I may be in a `Yes, Minister' position, as Senator Margetts indicates, and be snowed.

I just rise to say that we do not believe this should have priority today. It is an opportunity which Senator Spindler has taken to put his view on the record. We do not believe it should have priority. We believe that the integrity of the judicial system and of law enforcement agencies is at the centre of a free parliamentary system. But you do not make that point just by spending money; you actually have to achieve something when you do it. That is the problem we have at the moment with the state of knowledge of which we are in possession.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Greens do support Senator Spindler's motion to suspend standing orders to discuss at greater length the issue of an inquiry into the Hilton bombing. I will speak mainly to the urgency but, in recognition that we will not be considering the debate any further, I will mention some of the reasons relating to its seriousness because I feel that goes to the urgency as well.

PARA.TAB: We have only 16 sitting days left this year and possibly of this parliament. These are the most serious of unresolved allegations that will not go away. Senator Schacht said basically that this has been going on for 17 years, that it happened 17 years ago and that that was the reason it is not urgent. But one could also say that it becomes increasingly urgent to address it in order to withstand allegations that we are deliberately turning a blind eye to the matter.

However, some new matters have been raised. Recently, the new Premier of New South Wales has made a decision to release previously closed files on the matter. Also, Mr Pederick's lawyers have made a decision to petition the New South Wales Attorney-General for a review of Mr Pederick's conviction on the basis that he is no longer confident of his own admissions of involvement in the bombing.

This is a most serious matter that requires Senate scrutiny. It involves the unsolved murders arising from allegedly one of Australia's most serious acts of terrorism. I say `allegedly' because that is the crux of the outstanding allegations: was the bombing the result of some mysterious unidentified—up to now—terrorists; or were Australia's own security forces somehow involved in the bombing itself? Such allegations are of a serious nature. It would be improper for the Senate not to debate the motion at length before the Senate calls for an inquiry into the affair. The substantive motion calling for an inquiry is very similar to a motion moved by the member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) in the other place.

Basically, there are two sets of victims arising out of the Hilton bombing. One qualification I would give to the implied support of the Greens to the motion moved by Senator Spindler is that we need to prevent scapegoating of the second set of victims. The first set of victims are those who were killed or injured at the blast itself. People like Terry Griffiths, who has suffered years of physical pain and mental anguish, deserve to have all allegations concerning who was involved in the bombing cleared up.

The second set of victims are those who were wrongly accused and spent years in gaol after being convicted of the bombing. This is where I would like to sound a note of warning. While agreeing to support the suspension of standing orders so Senator Spindler's motion can be debated, we feel it is critical to note that, in calling for a further inquiry into the bombing, we should not allow the second set of victims to be further attacked.

An open-ended inquiry without specific terms of reference would allow previously discredited witnesses to try to resurrect failed police theories. Any future inquiry should look at the unresolved issues such as: were any members of the security forces in any way involved in the bombing; did any members have prior knowledge that the bombing was to take place; why were sniffer dogs not used to search for explosives prior to the bombing; when was the warning call to police received; and was it properly acted on?

Indeed, just last month, a report by the detective involved in the wrongful prosecution was tabled in the New South Wales parliament. Again, the detective tried to reignite old theories. Those like Tim Anderson, having already spent years in gaols for a crime that the courts later found they did not commit, were forced to defend themselves once again. There seems little doubt that an inquiry without proper terms of reference would cause certain interests to again peddle scapegoat theories. Here I have to agree with Senator Vanstone that we do need to make sure it is an effective inquiry. That is why there is a need for further debate. If we do not debate it here, who will and when will it be done?

It is clearly a Commonwealth government responsibility. The Commonwealth government has previously said it will cooperate with a New South Wales inquiry but that it sees the primary responsibility resting with New South Wales. However, the bombing occurred at a Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting where federal government agencies were in charge of security. The most serious allegations still outstanding involve Commonwealth security organisations, so clearly there is an onus on the federal government to act. Both of the major parties have indicated the seriousness of the Hilton bombing and the need to resolve it. I regret they are not supporting this motion. (Time expired)
