SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Officer education: the military after next together with submissions, the transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the joint standing committee, I have much pleasure in tabling the report entitled Officer education: the military after next. The report is the culmination of 12 months of considerable effort by members of the defence subcommittee. The reference from the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) asked the committee to examine the provision of academic studies and professional military education to officer cadets and officers of the Australian Defence Force. This involved an examination of nine training establishments, reviewing the suitability of the current system and then looking at what is needed in the future.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry has been particularly timely. At a time when there have been major changes to Australia's strategic environment and reductions in defence spending, it is appropriate that the professional development of ADF officers be re-examined. The committee undertook most seriously its task to look at the current training systems to ensure that we are preparing officers who will be able to lead the ADF into the 21st century, where a fundamentally different set of global, regional and national security arrangements will apply.

As mentioned earlier, the inquiry looked at nine colleges and the role they play in the professional development of the officer corps. The committee is aware of other pathways leading to professional military development and has commented on them in the report.

The profession of arms is uniquely demanding. It is also unique in that its members do not engage in their primary profession—war fighting—on an everyday basis. The problem facing the educators and trainers of military professionals is to prepare them not only for the eventuality of combat but also for the vast range of other tasks which military professionals perform in peacetime.

As the committee noted in its report, the ADF is to be commended for the high calibre of its officer corps. The members of the committee continue to be impressed by the professionalism and competence of the ADF officers we met on the course of the inquiry and on other activities undertaken by the committee, such as its attendance at the Kangaroo 95 exercise. The committee has been concerned that the high standards of officer performance should not diminish as a result of any reduction in resources allocated to Defence. An important goal of this inquiry, therefore, was to canvass ways in which academic studies and professional military education can be delivered more cost effectively to the officer corps to maintain the high standards already being achieved.

The report Officer education: the military after next is divided into five parts. The first four parts detail the findings of the committee on the system of professional development currently in place. In turn, pre-commissioning training, single service staff colleges and senior officer training as well as other avenues of professional development were discussed. The final section sets out the views of the committee on the suitability of the existing system for the future professional development of members of the officer corps.

Central to the whole report is the concept of the military after next. The concept emerged in the United States after the Gulf War. While I do not propose to go into much detail here about the concept and its implications for the ADF, I commend chapter 13 of this report to all senators with an interest in defence as it contains a very interesting discussion on these and related issues.

Central to this is the idea that middle and senior military commanders of the future will operate in a very different way from that typically conceived as the role of the commander today. Therefore, the committee believes it is imperative that the current system of providing academic studies and professional military education to officer cadets and officers of the ADF be able to produce officers who can effectively operate in this changed environment. Given the long lead times involved in producing middle and senior ranking officers in the ADF, the system of officer education needed to prepare these officers for the military after next therefore must be in place today. The report makes 20 recommendations in all, covering such issues as a comprehensive policy on higher education for officers, accreditation, a module approach to professional military studies and alternative delivery methods for the officer education system, such as distance education.

In the time remaining, I would briefly like to comment on recommendations 11 to 16, which will probably draw the most comment and discussion. These recommendations deal with the undergraduate program at the Australian Defence Force Academy, or ADFA. The committee has recommended that the university college undergraduate program conducted at ADFA be terminated and replaced by an undergraduate sponsorship scheme.

In looking at this matter, the committee examined the rationale for the establishment of the Australian Defence Force Academy. While there was controversy at the time about the decision to establish ADFA, the committee recognises that the ADF has benefited from that decision. ADFA has guaranteed a stream of officers with a university education. Jointery was a ground-breaking feature for ADFA.

The academy has produced high quality officers for the ADF to captain equivalent. However, the environment has changed considerably since that decision to establish the academy was taken. The committee has reassessed ADFA in today's environment and against future needs and demands. Some members of the committee felt it was still too early to assess the ADFA experiment and to fully assess it in terms of the officers it produces. However, the majority of the committee did feel that it was possible to make a valid assessment of ADFA now.

The committee was concerned that an education at ADFA may not be an appropriate mechanism for integrating officer cadets into the community they are going to serve. Increasingly, the ADF needs to be part of, and draw from, the community. Potential officers are isolated and treated very differently from their peers in the community while they undertake their tertiary studies. In addition, the artificial ADFA environment means that cadets are not generally forced to face the very real issue of why they are part of the ADF at all.

In the committee's view, the insular and institutionalised nature of officer development militates against proper integration and interaction with members of the community. The committee is concerned that the sheltered environment of ADFA may not be capable of consistently producing the type of officer which will be necessary in the military after next: one that is able to display initiative, lateral thinking, elements of risk taking, strong motivation, versatility and flexibility.

The committee believes that recruiting graduates from civilian universities will benefit the ADF through the greater maturity of its potential officer corps at commissioning. These officers will have benefited from interaction with the civilian community during their university studies. In addition, they will have the advantage of forming associations with potential industrialists, public servants and others in a wider network than Defence.

There are also significant resource aspects to this whole debate. The cost to Defence of the existing officer training system is $200 million. Of this, approximately 50 per cent, or $97.5 million, is spent on ADFA. If you do an examination of total students at all Defence colleges, you will find that approximately half of the total ADF college funding is spent on only about one-third of the total number of students. This raises the question of whether too high a proportion of the Defence training budget is being allocated to providing academic education to too small a proportion of the officer corps.

The report argues that there are two main ways in which Defence could recruit graduates from civilian universities. Defence could simply compete with other employers for recruits as students graduate, or they could seek to involve students in Defence activities during their studies by way of a sponsorship scheme or similar mechanisms. The committee has favoured the latter approach, as it provides Defence with a closer connection with the students, thereby enabling Defence to monitor their performance and level of interest throughout their undergraduate studies. It also provides Defence and the students with an opportunity to undertake military training during university semester breaks.

The undergraduate sponsorship scheme proposed by the committee has a number of distinguishing features. It targets approximately 1,000 graduate students per year for financial assistance in civilian universities. Allowing for normal attrition, 800 students would remain in the scheme at the end of year two, and 600 by the end of year three. From these, the ADF could select the most suitable 300 or so officer cadets for pre-commissioning training. Other suitable candidates could be offered commissions in the reserve forces or be recruited into other ranks, regular or reserve.

While undertaking their undergraduate studies, students will embark upon a single service and common military training program during extended academic breaks. This would include some basic training, familiarisation and motivational visits to Defence establishments and observation of, and participation in, a range of enterprises.

Sponsored students would be administered and supported by a regional office, which would take responsibility for arranging a single service in the common military training program during extended academic breaks. Selection into the scheme and the ADF upon completion of studies should be competitive. Recruitment for the ADF should rest on academic and military aptitude with no guarantee of employment upon graduation.

I commend this section of the report, in particular, to all interested in officer education in Australia. I know it is going to provide some people with food for thought and make people maybe argue their positions as to why they have certain beliefs and why they hold them now. That is not a bad thing when we are looking at the expenditure of government money and when we are looking at the training of officer cadets who are potential officers in the ADF.

In conclusion, I would like to thank the staff involved in the inquiry process and the production of the final report: Gillian Gould and Matthew Mason-Cox, who were, in turn, secretary of the defence subcommittee during this inquiry; Wing Commander Ken Given, who was seconded to the secretariat for the first half of 1995 and who provided invaluable background knowledge and assistance to the subcommittee; and Mr Peter McLay, who provided excellent administrative assistance to the subcommittee during this inquiry. I commend this report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the inquiry into officer education. I wrote a brief dissenting report. I acknowledge that on a number of occasions the committee was aware of my concerns and did, as far as possible, acknowledge them.

PARA.TAB: At page 9 of the report, paragraph 2.2 states, in relation to the attendance of students from overseas defence forces at the colleges identified in the terms of reference:

SPEECH.PARA: while the attendance of these overseas students provides valuable opportunities to establish military networks and further promotes Australia's policy of regional engagement, these views were not shared by all members of the Committee.

I acknowledge that that member was me. I felt it necessary to point out the reasons why I had concerns with this. I have pointed this out in my short dissenting report. It is mainly because of the fact that we have evidence that a number of the officers from countries in our region who have been educated at Australian establishments have been involved in corps which have been involved in human rights abuses. We think that sounds a wrong message.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to see some acknowledgment that we could include a greater percentage of courses which deal with the rule of law in Australia. I think there is a problem in terms of general military training for officers when it is difficult to establish training in relation to an external conflict or an internal conflict. If we are talking about human rights abuses involved in the quelling of internal conflict, we might be training people who use that training to assist in perpetrating human right abuses. This is very difficult for us to control at this end.

A lot of the discussions which have occurred in relation to this have focused on the fact that by a form of osmosis officers from other countries who are mixing with officers from Australia, New Zealand or similar countries may take on the general ethos of the host country; they may take on the values of the other students in the course. If that is the theory, it should be the same in reverse. There are people whose general method of operation includes quelling of dissent by brutal means. Surely those values might, by reverse osmosis, be integrated into the beliefs and further actions of our own officers. I am not saying that the osmosis is the way it is happening. If it is happening in one direction, surely there is a possibility that it could happen in reverse.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is drawing a long bow.

—There has been an interjection that that is a long bow. If the argument is that officers will largely gain those human rights values by association, then the only conclusion you could draw is that that association could create the opposite effect in terms of other officers.

PARA.TAB: Paragraph 13.45 notes that members of the Australian Defence Force provide advice to and liaison with members of parliament and the community generally. The reason this is mentioned in a report on training, I think, is very important. I know from my experience at Senate estimates that on occasions we get sharp retorts either from the minister or from the military, for instance, on requests for information, that it is not the job of members of the Australian Defence Force to `take time off their real job to answer questions'. I would say very strongly that in the democracy of which we are a part this is part of the real job of any defence force.

If you do not train officers to communicate defence policy and if you present a general picture to them that it is not their job and it is an inconvenience, then they are not going to be fulfilling their democratic role correctly, which is communicating policy, as all government funded bodies are required to do from time to time, to elected bodies. You are going to make it possible for people in those positions not to be particularly skilful in carrying out those duties. It will take a lot longer to get any information on the public record back to the parliamentary representatives. The whole process will be more difficult.

This would not be such a point of criticism if it were not for the fact that quite a deal of resources in military establishments, in communicating policies—not to us, not to the parliamentary representatives and not through the process—is being used to present that information in order to sell policies and to sell upcoming programs to defence industry. I get very angry when it is possible for defence industry to get reports well before we get access to them or to get them when we do not get offered either the report or the information.

If there is a lot of effort going into the training of officers to communicate so well with industry, perhaps some of that effort has to go into communicating defence policy more succinctly and more naturally within the democratic process. Then we would not feel so suspicious that information was being held back. If it is on the public record, it should be more available to the people.

Defence expenditure is a very big expenditure. For the public to feel that that expenditure is being spent in the right way it is necessary for that communication to take place and those people in Defence who still feel it is not their role should get used to it. This is part of what Defence is supposed to do.

There is one specific course in the colleges dealing with human rights. It is at the College of Defence and Strategic Studies. It had a human rights component. The focus, they said, was on the connection between the professional life of the officer, human rights norms and the objectives they are expected to fulfil. SPEECH.PARA: The Customs Tariff Bill 1995 introduces the new customs tariff act to come into effect on the 1st July 1996. The act will replace the Customs Tariff Act 1987 as announced in the context of the government's 1994 white paper, "working nation".

The new customs tariff will incorporate some 350 changes to the international convention on the harmonized commodity description and coding system proposed by the World customs organization. Australia became a signatory to the convention in 1987. In 1993, the World customs organization agreed to these changes. Australia is now giving effect to our obligations to align our tariff structure with the international standard.

The bill will also renumber and update the wording of the legal provisions in the current tariff. The bill removes unnecessary tariff splits in schedule 3 and redefines some of the concessional provisions contained in schedule 4.
I will now outline the changes contained in this bill in more detail.

The legal provisions of the current act have been amended since 1987 on an ad hoc basis to cater for changes to the treatment accorded goods from certain countries and for other purposes. The new act will consolidate these changes and renumber the provisions. There are also textual changes.

Schedule one provides a new listing of countries which benefit under the Australian system of tariff preferences for developing countries. In 1991 and 1993 the government decided to phase out the developing country margin of preference for goods produced or manufactured in all except the least developed countries. The new listings within schedule one group these countries according to the tariff treatment which they receive. Overall, the intention of these amendments is to retain the existing provisions of the current act but to present them in a more logical and orderly sequence.

Schedule three presents the list of customs classification and duty rates applicable to goods. It is in this schedule that the three hundred and fifty changes recommended by the World customs organization occur. The changes reflect differing patterns in international trade and technological developments. Their aim is to regroup like products in the same subheadings and to correct anomalies which have become apparent in the harmonized system.
The government has tried to maintain existing duty rates wherever possible. To maintain the existing levels some additional 200 national splits were created in the tariff.

In one case, that relating to snowboard boots, local industry and importers have defined the essential characteristics of the boots for a tariff precedent. This will allay concerns that other boots, which are now dutiable, could enter duty free.
In only five cases have duty rates not been preserved.

The rate of duty for graded and ungraded pearls, whether or not strung for the convenience of transport, will be free, in line with current practice. Graded pearls are sold, according to accepted international practice, as `temporarily strung for transport purposes'. As Australia currently has a duty on strung pearls, but not on those unstrung, Australian industry practice has been to import the pearls unstrung. This will no longer be required from the 1st July 1996.

The duty rate for waste and scrap of batteries will be set at free. While this does not reflect the existing rate for waste of mercury and lithium batteries, it is supported by industry. They have advised that there are no imports of such waste and scrap into Australia nor are there any plans to do so in the future.

Tyre cord fabrics of woven glass fibres and other woven fabrics of glass will be combined in new subheadings.There have been no imports from developing countries over the last five years of these tyre cord fabrics. The duty rate for developing countries will therefore be that applying to other woven fabrics of glass.
It has not been possible to identify separately the specific goods which transfer between subheadings in 2 instances: food preparations containing cocoa and input or output units for computers.

The World Customs Organization has altered the basis of the calculation of cocoa content for certain food preparations. As such it has not been possible to identify separately the specific food preparations which are transferring to an existing subheading. The duty rate proposed reflects the rate of the predominant proportion of trade, some 92 percent, within the expanded subheading.

Input or output units (for computers), for example keyboards and printers, from five existing subheadings are combining into one new subheading. The proposed duty rate will reflect the rate applicable to ninety eight percent of the total trade in those subheadings.

Some national splits in tariff subheadings have been proposed that may eventually prove to be unnecessary because there is no trade. These subheadings will be examined when adequate statistics become available. If the situation so requires, proposals will be brought forward to close-up the subheadings whose tariff splits are serving no purpose.

Following the implementation of the Customs tariff act 1995, administrative arrangements will be established within the department of industry, science and technology and the Australian Customs service whereby aggrieved parties, including our trading partners, may raise concerns if anomalous situations arise in the context of the government's decision to preserve the duty arrangements. The appeal period will extend from the 1st July 1996 to the thirtieth of june 1997.
Mr President, I now draw your attention to amendments to schedule 4 of the customs tariff bill.
Schedule 4 contains the list of concessional provisions. The three key changes proposed relate to items 17, 18 and 20, which are all re-import provisions.

Item 17 allows for goods that have been exported from Australia, other than for repair and renovation, to re-enter Australia without being penalised by having to pay duty a second time if their identity has not been altered. It was intended that under this item goods are returned in an unaltered condition, and have not been subject to treatment, industrial processing, repair, renovation, alteration or any other process.

It has become apparent, however, that the current wording of the item allows its use for wider purposes. For instance, some goods are re-entering Australia after undergoing industrial processing in another country. The amendments are intended to ensure that item 17 cannot be used where any industrial processing has been undertaken overseas before re-importation.

Item 18 permits goods or parts of goods to re-enter Australia duty free in accordance with the provisions of a specific warranty. The changes in item 18c will extend these provisions to goods subject to a global recall for safety or related reasons.

Item 20 permits the re-entry of goods sent overseas for repair and renovation, but requires that duty be paid on the value of the repair or renovation. These provisions will be retained as the new item 20a. Item 20b contains a new concessional provision. International best practice for repair and renovation dictates that for many purposes, batch repair be undertaken. This means that the faulty product is swapped with an identical unit already repaired. The good sent for repair is then stored until sufficient numbers of the same product have accumulated for economical repair.
Under the present operation of item 20, companies are being charged duty on the full value of the items exchanged under such arrangements, rather than on the value of the repairs.

Australia needs to recognise the move internationally to batch repair processing. The new item 20b, with related by-law, will allow companies to enter into agreements with Customs to introduce batch repair arrangements without penalty.

The by-law arrangements will be similar to those applying to the tariff export concessions or texco scheme, on goods which the company will send overseas for batch repair, prior to re-importation. The new item 20b by-law will permit companies to take advantage of batch repair process arrangements whilst allowing Customs to ensure compliance concerns are met.

Once a company has such an agreement and is registered, it will be able to use the by-law. Companies will need to retain documentation demonstrating that they are meeting the provisions of the by-law. Customs will employ risk management techniques to ensure that the government's policy intent is being met.

As well as proposals to modify items 17, 18 and 20 a number of administrative changes to a range of other schedule 4 items are proposed. These changes are minor, and will improve the administration of the schedule.
The proposed changes include the rationalisation of numbering to fill unused items, and the splitting of items where appropriate.

Some of the previous items had coverage of two or more types of goods and it has been difficult to issue specific by-laws for these goods. These have been split into separate items to facilitate their administration.
A summary of amendments contained in this bill has been prepared and circulated to honourable Senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill amends the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 (the act) to implement budget decisions to increase student places and research funding. The costs of these initiatives will be offset by the reallocation of existing discretionary funds, reduction of pipeline places for Victoria, and refinements to the higher education contribution scheme (HECS).

PARA.TAB: The 1995-96 federal budget decisions reflected in this bill demonstrate clearly that the government is maintaining its commitment to the development of a high quality and accessible higher education system. They also confirm the government's ongoing policy of no up-front fees for Australian undergraduate students. They strengthen the government's commitment to HECS as the mechanism whereby Australian undergraduate students make an equitable contribution to the cost of their education. The changes in HECS build on the essential features of the scheme and bring forward revenue which will assist growth of the higher education sector without increasing the size of any student's HECS debt or reducing the thresholds at which repayments must commence.

The act sets out maximum amounts for grants to institutions. This bill amends the act to reflect changes in expenditure as a result of the budget initiatives to provide new places, additional research funds and the carry-forward of quality funds. The bill includes funding for 1997 and 1998.

The amendments provide funding for 5,850 new higher education places, plus pipeline, in the years 1996-1998. These places will go to states with strong population growth and currently low participation rates. Queensland will be the major beneficiary of these new places; New South Wales, Tasmania and Western Australia will also receive some places. The higher education budget package provides for funding of growth in other states in 1999.

The Victorian government has previously expressed fears that as many as 10,000 higher education places would be redistributed from Victoria to other states to address growing differences in higher education participation rates and population growth. The provision of extra places to Queensland, New South Wales, Tasmania and Western Australia has, however, been achieved without any reduction in the existing funding level or number of places at any university. There will be a minor reallocation of some of the growth anticipated in Victoria, but Victorian institutions will still experience small increases in both funds and places and participation and access rates in Victoria will remain significantly higher than in any other state until at least 2003.

Amendments to the act also increase the total funds available for research infrastructure to about $293m over the 1996-98 triennium. This represents an additional $109m for research infrastructure. This reflects the government's consistent view that an adequate research infrastructure is crucial for universities to maintain their research and research training capacity at internationally competitive levels.

The amendments also provide an additional $40m for competitive research grants to assist the nation to maintain and strengthen its research capabilities and to enhance the contribution made by research and scientific development to national economic and social goals. This funding will be made available through the Australian Research Council and is on top of the $350m already committed for these purposes over the 1996-98 triennium.

There is also a welcome boost to opportunities available for outstanding research students. From 1996 there will be an extra 100 Australian postgraduate awards on top of the 1600 already available. In addition there will be 5 new postdoctoral fellowships making a total of 55 from 1996.

The amendments establish the higher education innovations program. This program amalgamates the national priority (reserve) fund and the quality assurance program. The higher education innovations program will continue to provide incentives to maintain and enhance the quality of higher education as well as provide funding for specific innovative projects of national priority.
All of the initiatives outlined are achieved without any net additional expenditure and without introducing up-front fees for Australian undergraduate students.

A vital element in this package is a set of refinements to HECS which bring forward revenue but do not increase the size of an individual's HECS debt. It is only by making these changes that the government is able to deliver substantial improvements in the higher education sector without recourse to the easy, but fiscally irresponsible, course of increasing overall government expenditure.
One such refinement introduces an extra incentive for early repayment of HECS debts by allowing a 15 per cent discount on voluntary payments of $500 or more.

Another initiative introduces a voluntary option whereby HECS debtors can elect to repay their debt at a lower threshold and receive a 10 per cent discount. If HECS debtors elect to take up the option, they will make a commitment to repay their accumulated HECS debt at 2 per cent of assessable income when they are above a specified threshold ($20,000 in 1995-96), but below the first compulsory threshold ($27,674 in 1995-96). Their outstanding HECS debt will then be reduced by 10 per cent.

This change will not be mandatory. A person choosing to take up the offer will lodge an election form with the Australian taxation office which will `trigger' the discount and repayments when the person falls within the specified income range.

These initiatives build on the essential features of the HECS scheme. They not only benefit the commonwealth through earlier repayment of HECS debts, but provide a significant benefit to the HECS debtor by introducing discounts in the size of their HECS debt.

The government has created a more flexible, accessible and dynamic higher education system and is committed to introducing policies that make further improvements. The government, however, believes that its policies for access to publicly-funded higher education should meet, first and foremost, the needs of Australian citizens and those who have demonstrated a long term commitment to Australia.

Consistent with this, the act amends the HECS provisions so that new Zealand citizens, and Australian permanent residents of three years standing or more who have not become Australian citizens, pay their HECS contributions up-front at enrolment. They will also have no further access to the open learning deferred payment scheme (OLDPS). Those students who have had their application for citizenship approved by the department of immigration and ethnic affairs, may continue to defer their HECS and OLDPS contributions. This will ensure that students who have had a citizenship application approved but who may have to wait some months to attend a citizenship conferral ceremony will not be financially disadvantaged.
As with other changes to HECS, the revenue brought forward as a result of this change will be used to fund additional higher education student places.

The discount on mandatory up-front HECS payments is removed by these amendments. Under HECS, students who pay their contribution up-front at enrolment receive a discount of 25 per cent on their payment. This provides an incentive to pay up-front. This is not appropriate for those students who are precluded from deferring their contribution.

Another measure relates to the provision of HECS exemption scholarships for teachers. These scholarships were introduced in 1989 to support a greater degree of professional development among teachers. Since that time the government has introduced a new, more flexible $60m national professional development program which addresses much the same objectives. As a result of this initiative, and in light of the priority to provide additional undergraduate opportunities, the $4.8m previously allocated to teacher HECS exemption scholarships will be reallocated to help create student places. In future, commonwealth support for the professional development of teachers will be provided solely through the national professional development program. As the scholarship program will cease from the end of 1995, there will be no need for a provision in the act exempting scholarship holders from HECS liability and the act will be amended accordingly.

Currently under HECS there are three rates of repayment—3 per cent, 4 per cent and 5 per cent of taxable income—depending on the debtor's level of taxable income. As part of the 1995 budget, the government is introducing four additional repayment rates of 3.5 per cent, 4.5 per cent, 5.5 per cent and 6 per cent of HECS repayment income.

The 3.5 per cent and 4.5 per cent rates are intermediate repayment rates and operate in a range between existing threshold levels. The 5.5 per cent and 6 per cent rates are additional repayment rates, being set above the existing maximum threshold level. These additional repayment thresholds will return revenue to the commonwealth at a faster rate without increasing the size of the HECS debt for individuals.

An amendment to the act also redefines taxable income for HECS assessment purposes. From 1 July 1996, if a HECS debtor's taxable income has been reduced by a net rental loss (commonly referred to as "negative gearing"), then for HECS assessment purposes the amount of rental loss claimed will be added to the debtor's taxable income. For income earned in the income year 1996-97 and in subsequent income years, HECS assessable income will be used to determine whether or not a HECS debtor is required to make a compulsory repayment against their HECS debt.

It is a principle underlying HECS that students in publicly-funded higher education places should be expected to make a contribution towards the cost of their tuition when, and only when, they have the financial capacity to do so. It is the government's intention that, by instituting this budget measure, those with the financial capacity to repay their HECS debt but who are in a position to minimise their income by claiming rental loss in their individual tax return, will no longer be able to avoid making repayments of their HECS contribution.

In summary, I stress that this bill presents a very tightly integrated package of measures which provides for growth in student places where they are needed, enhances research funds and postgraduate scholarships, does not alter the fundamental elements of HECS nor require reallocation of any existing student places, and does not increase overall government outlays. This package, or "cocktail" as it became known in the higher education sector, was developed following extensive consultation with the higher education sector.

As I indicated at the time the budget was handed down, any attempt to unravel this package or to introduce amendments which reduce revenue raising aspects will mean that the government is forced to reconsider its announcement of additional places allocated to Queensland, New South Wales, western Australia and Tasmania. Alternatively, the government will have to consider the reallocation of existing places from other states.

Through this package, mr speaker, the government has responded positively and quickly to the resource needs of the higher education sector with both new policy and effective savings without cutting the overall funds available to higher education.

This bill underscores this government's commitment to the provision of opportunities for all Australians to have access to higher education; access which is dependant on academic merit and ability not on the capacity to pay.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the senate.

I want to make a brief comment in relation to Senator Kemp';s comments. Our previous amendments dealt with the design of products. These amendments deal with the products themselves. Whilst they may seem technical and they may seem complicated, they are definitely improvements to the legislation and have been discussed with people who are very familiar with these matters and who feel that it is a logical and a consistent way for the legislation to approach design and production. The reason is that it is looking practically at how industry can best approach our ozone protection regime. In that case, we should give them every direction possible for certainty and consistency in the way in which we approach it.

PARA.TAB: Amendments 15 to 22 have the effect of stopping the use of all scheduled substances in various products including aerosol cans, dry cleaning, disposable containers and various foams. We should note that, for the most part, industry no longer uses scheduled products in these applications. For example, aerosol cans now almost exclusively use hydrocarbon propellants. There is no reason to allow manufacturers to start using substances such as HCFCs or, indeed, HFCs—the hydrofluorocarbons. Stopping HFC use was part of the original intent of this amendment. If we did not stop them we would be moving backwards environmentally.

Although that was the original intent, it makes no difference to these amendments since they simply change phases like phase 1 and phase 2 substances to any scheduled substances. This has the effect of explicitly including in the restriction the HBFCs, HCFCs and methyl bromide. I cannot imagine anyone wanting to use those substances, with the possible exception of HCFCs, in any application covered here. As a result, I can see no problem in implementing this. This relates specifically to amendments 15 to 22. I want to go through each amendment in turn because they relate to different products.

Amendment 15 relates to dry cleaning equipment. The amendment prohibits the use of all scheduled substances. Currently the act prohibits the use of schedule 1 parts I, II, III and IV only. Dry cleaning does not currently appear to commonly use any scheduled substance, thus ensuring that it is clear that dry cleaning does not use such substances and should have no impact.

Amendments 16 and 17 relate to disposable or non-refillable containers for, respectively, auto airconditioning maintenance kits and refrigerants generally. Disposable containers and kits are generally for backyard type applications and servicing, and work against recycling and monitoring. That is why they were banned in the first place. This would explicitly extend that ban to other scheduled substances, particularly the HCFCs which are the only substances likely to be affected by this amendment.

In Western Australia the Motor Trades Association has been complaining for years about the lack of inspection and enforcement of state law regarding ozone depleting substances. The association complains that many backyard mechanics and body shops do not recycle but vent gases to air. The recycling equipment is expensive and there is a significant labour component to recycling, making vent to air a much cheaper option. Just in case senators think we are being technical here, all that `vent to air' means is that you take the equipment out of the refrigerator or the airconditioner and just let it go into the air. It is not a technical term.

Faced with price competition from unscrupulous mechanics, those who did the right thing and bought recycling equipment found that they could not afford to use it because they were competing with people who were not doing the right thing. Current concerns by the same group—which were voiced by my colleague Jim Scott in the upper house of the state parliament—are that licences to deal with CFCs do not apply to many of the alternatives. This means that an unlicensed mechanic can vent CFCs to air and replace them with HFCs. While enforcement of state law and conditions and the application of licences are a state affair, disposable kits will certainly make it more difficult to regulate. This was the rationale behind the original restriction regarding CFCs. Our amendment would stop the use of these kits for HCFCs and HBFCs. It would also cover the use of methyl bromide, but this is not used as a refrigerant or airconditioning substance.

Amendment 19 concerns aerosols. We really do not want to see HCFCs or other environmentally destructive products promoted to this application as the chemical industry is trying to do. Hydrocarbons are already the industry standard, and that is what we should be working towards.

Amendment 18 covers polystyrene packaging and insulation; amendment 20 covers rigid polyurethane foam; and amendment 21 covers flexible polyurethane foam. Basically there is no longer any excuse for using any scheduled substance as a foam blowing agent. Most foam blowing in OECD countries is done using cyclopentanes or other hydrocarbons because they are cheaper, have less environmental impact, and are generally safer in an occupational safety sense during manufacture.

This amendment would have an impact on developing nations where the World Bank has assisted in the establishment of plants using HCFCs as foam blowing agents. It is generally accepted that HCs are cheaper and safer foam blowing agents. Even the World Bank is starting to rethink its position. I believe all Australian refrigerator manufacturers now use hydrocarbon foams.

With regard to amendment 22, I have to say that I am not sure why schedule 4 proposed clause 9 was included without deleting existing clause 3, since they are virtually identical. I call this anomaly to the attention to the minister and suggest that either clause 3 or clause 9 should be deleted. The major difference is that clause 3 includes all part I, II, III and IV substances, though only part I substances—that is CFCs—are used as refrigerants. Clause 9 says that it only applies to CFCs and not to HCFCs or HBFCs. Clause 3 may be a bit more specific and applies only to containers of five kilos or less. Clause 9 has no weight limit and only applies to products consisting wholly of disposable containers. Proposed clause 9 covers products that are wholly or partly disposable containers. Our amendment applied to clause 9 would effectively result in a restriction in relation to HCFCs and HBFCs as well as CFCs.

I recommend our amendments 15 to 22 as being a simple statement of restriction in relation to all scheduled substances, instead of naming some and not others, on the assumption that those not named specifically will not be used. A general statement in relation to scheduled substances covers everything, allows consistency, and would cover any new substances added—as HBFCs have been added this year. If the government and the coalition will not support our amendments I ask that they specify for the record what they will do to meet the legitimate concerns on these issues and limit the amount of new equipment using scheduled substances that are manufactured or imported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 23 refers specifically to domestic refrigerators and splits them off from commercial or industrial refrigerators and commercial, industrial or domestic airconditioning equipment. Domestic refrigeration has not wholly adopted hydrocarbon technologies, but is rapidly doing so. This amendment says that no scheduled substances should be used by 1998. Given that most developed world companies no longer use scheduled substances for foam blowing and most are converting to non-scheduled refrigerants or have done so, particularly the EC, this should not be a problem in Australia. The US has problems in this area because cyclic defrost machines are harder to design for hydrocarbons, but even the United States' industry is converting. Commercial and industrial chillers using some HCFCs are very efficient and alternatives have not been available, although at least one large chain, I think Coles, has converted to chillers refrigerated with ammonia.

PARA.TAB: Domestic airconditioning uses HCFCs and there are currently few commercial alternatives. Nonetheless, the CEPA suggested privately in a discussion that it would be helpful to set a cut-off date for new HCFC equipment at 1998. This would ensure that industry is not locked into the extended use of a substance that is being phased out—a particularly important measure since commercial and industrial refrigeration and airconditioning equipment is expensive and has a normal lifetime of 20 years or more.

The phase-out of HCFCs would ensure that there is gas to continue to service a limited amount of existing equipment, but we should make certain that there is as little of such equipment as possible to service. This amendment does that for HCFCs and also HFCs. Since we have failed to have a new part 8 included to cover HFCs, I will ask that reference to this part in our amendment be deleted.

Another new class of product, vehicle airconditioners, has been included. Auto airconditioning is a contentious issue in relation to HFCs versus hydrocarbons, but it is likely that hydrocarbons can either be used safely now, as indicated in the Little report that has just been released, or can be made safe to use.

Two possible safety measures are: firstly, a pressure sensor attached to an alarm which would go off if pressure dropped below a certain level, which is effective for slow or sudden leaks; or, secondly, assuring adequate ventilation in the passenger compartment so that a sudden total release of refrigerant into the compartment would disperse beyond the point of flammability within 30 seconds when standing still with the windows closed. One study shows the average modern car is designed with sufficient ventilation for dispersal within 50 seconds. I think this is the answer to the question Senator Kemp raised earlier. In any case, it is clear that HCFCs do not need to be used since both HFCs and HCs are commercially available and neither are ozone depleting substances. To allow HCFCs to be used would be highly irresponsible.

Again, the way our original amendment was written assumed that there would be a part 8 of schedule 1. In its absence, I ask that subclause 2 on applications be deleted so the amendment will simply say `that no scheduled substance should be used in a vehicle airconditioning equipment'. This would effectively only apply to HCFCs and so is unlikely to have a major impact on industry.

I will not call a division on this amendment or my other amendments. I understand that the government will not support them. I also think I am fairly right to anticipate Senator Kemp's response that the opposition will not be supporting them. It is not good enough to say that industry will sort it out. It is pretty clear that industry does not sort these issues out unless it is pushed, and often only acts when they are regulated. In any case, my understanding is that the EPA is inundated with requests from industry about what it should do since the government has already interfered and told them they cannot use CFCs.

It is simple enough at this point to avoid a lot of grief and clearly tell industry that HCFCs are not to be used if there is any alternative and that the same should apply to HFCs. All possible assistance in converting to alternatives, whether hydrocarbon, ammonia, or whatever, should be given. This includes doing whatever is required to develop methods to ensure that hydrocarbons can be used safely in the few applications where any doubt about safety remains. I ask the minister and the shadow minister to explicitly address the need to stop as rapidly as possible the use of HCFCs and HFCs. I move:

I would like to get the minister's comments on amendment No. 1 before going on to Nos 2 and 3. The amendments on page 3956 relate to the accelerated phase-out of HCFCs and methol bromide. The first amendment, which relates to schedule 1, page 8, says that no licences for use of methol bromide will extend past 30 June 2001. The USA is currently pushing for this limit and is suggesting a trade restriction penalising products produced using methol bromide. Methol bromide is used as an agricultural fumigant. It is an ozone depleting substance and a greenhouse gas. It differs from CFCs and other gases because it is routinely released to the atmosphere in use. It is used as a fumigant because it can kill virtually anything in soil. But aside from its impact on the ozone layer and on global warming, killing everything in the soil is not a good agricultural practice. A great deal of what is in the soil is very valuable in agriculture.

PARA.TAB: Rhizobium, a soil fungus, is responsible for most of the nitrogen fixation in legumes and clovers, and earthworms keep the soil friable. Other micro-organisms and invertebrates work to maintain pH, increase the friability of soil, and repress pathogenic and pest organisms. Soil is created and maintained by these small friends of agriculture, and general poisons destroy them and damage the soil, increasing compaction and the likelihood that the pest organisms gain a foothold. So there are good agricultural reasons to move away from the use of methol bromide and towards integrated and biological pest controls. In any case, there is no clear strategy for phasing out bromide in spite of strong action being taken in other nations. This amendment would set a date for phase-out. If the government rejects this amendment, I would like to know what it plans to do instead.

Amendments Nos 2 and 3, which work together, accelerate the phase-out of HCFCs. They would terminate their general use by 2010. The accelerated schedule is in line with suggestions in the US and other nations and is the target for phase-outs supported by Greenpeace. Amendment No. 2 relates to the industry limits.
