DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL 1994 [NO. 2]FAMILY LAW REFORM (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 November 1994 and 29 March, on motions by Senators Faulkner and Crowley:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be debating for the remainder of the afternoon—no doubt tomorrow as well—the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 [No. 2] and the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995. These bills have been before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee twice, which is not a bad thing. They have been available for heaven knows how long for everybody to have their say on and, indeed, just about everybody has had their say. I do not say that in a pejorative or condescending sense. It is a good thing when legislation before this parliament is subjected to full and proper scrutiny, to committee consideration, and when interest groups in the community—from the Law Council in general, the Family Law Council, the national Women's Justice Commission—and a very wide range of people, have had the opportunity to have some input into this bill.

PARA.TAB: While it is not true to say that it will be substantially changed—I do not believe that is a fair assessment of it—nonetheless, as a consequence of those committee hearings and of the contributions made by people such as those that I have mentioned, there will be some significant amendments that the government has shown it has been prepared to make, which we will be supporting.

A number of contentious issues need to be considered with respect to this bill. I do not want to take all the time available to me now. I believe there are 86 government amendments, so there will be plenty of opportunity to make any points that people need to make. But I would like to touch on a couple of points.

The first is the question of the imprisonment of registrars for carelessly or recklessly releasing information. There has to be some distinction, some dividing line, between people who are Family Court judges and judicial registrars. The community is entitled to expect family law matters to be treated confidentially and, where they are not, the community is entitled to expect some serious consequence. I look forward to hearing what the Greens (WA) have to say with respect to that matter. That is one matter on which we would expect in the committee stage to have some significant debate.

Equally, with respect to parenting plans, there needs to be some teasing out of everbody's positions. There are two strains of thought on agreed parenting plans which, if the government has its way, one can register without having had legal advice and with only some cursory looking at by the court. One school of thought says, `That's a good thing. Half of the problem with the Family Court is the family lawyers.' Plenty of people would say that some family lawyers are driving around in the most modern, hotted-up versions of Mercedes sports cars, Porches and everything else. That may be true of some, but it is not true of all. Plenty of family lawyers take their professional responsibilities very responsibly. In my view, that is an attack generally made by people who are somewhat ill-informed about the issues relating to the high costs of justice. It is just so easy to kick the legal profession and blame them.

I just want to put on record the confidence that we have in the legal profession, acknowledging that they have some bad apples as does every other industry—and, perhaps, Mr Acting Deputy President, you and I could agree that that comment could apply even to us. You and I would not like to be criticised on the basis of a wrongdoing by a member of a federal or state parliament—the assumption being that we were all the same. I am sure family lawyers fit into that category. They are, after all, operating in a system designed by us and administered by the judges. They do not make the policies; we do. So I wanted to make that view clear, with the rider that there would be some lawyers in the family law jurisdiction, as there would be in any other area, as there would be in any other service industry, that run up costs unnecessarily. But one swallow does not a summer or a spring make. I do not think it is fair to criticise the entire profession on that basis.

Nonetheless, those criticisms encourage people to say, `Don't let the lawyers into this. If the husband and wife agree, leave them to it.' The other side says, `Those people that want to come to an agreement and are capable of coming to an agreement without any animosity between them as to these matters, can still do that.' Plenty of them now do. Plenty of them now do not avail themselves of the Family Court at your and my expense, because they can sort it out themselves—and they have a very flexible arrangement because they have no written agreements. Given that they are getting on but not wanting to be married any more, they can handle changes in their situations with a minimum of fuss.

The difficulty comes for the parties that cannot do that. The notion here is to let them register these agreements. There is some concern that if these are to be treated as orders of the court, then the court has to have even a cursory scrutiny of the matters contained in the agreement. One cannot imagine this government wanting agreements registered that are not in the best interests of the child. We will settle all that in this debate. Presumably, there must be that cursory look. The real question comes as to whether you will require both parties to have received legal advice prior to the court agreeing to register the agreement as though it were a court order, understanding the court will not move to enforce the orders if there is a breach unless the court then satisfies itself at a later stage that the agreement is in the best interests of the child. I understand that.

But if consequences hang on this, if it is something more than just a rubber stamp that the parties are committing themselves to, then there is a serious question to be considered as to the rights of the parties signing the agreement. If nothing hangs on it and it is as though they were one of the couples that make an agreement outside the court, then no-one would worry. But if something hangs on it—and presumably something does, otherwise this is a very expensive farce that we are going into—not the least of which are the rights of one or other of the parties and the difficulty and cost in getting the agreement changed where circumstances change and the parties cannot come to an agreement as to how it ought to change, then there is a fair case for saying that someone ought to have some legal advice before they commit themselves to that.

I will be interested to hear what Senator Neal has to say in this respect. Rumour has it that she practised as a family lawyer. I have never bothered to check. That may be right. Perhaps those who do not know will find that out in the debate. I will be interested to hear her view as to whether women, who are traditionally seen as being in the least powerful position, would benefit from having advice before they put their name at the bottom of one of these agreements.

Plenty of people, especially in times of stress, such as when a marriage is breaking up and decisions are being made as to what to do with the children, do not necessarily think as far down the track as they might want to. Just like people who want to make a will think of it in terms of the assets that they now have, the children that they now have, the friends that they now have, and if you let them draft one themselves, they would probably make a botch of it in effectively distributing their assets in accordance with their wishes under the changed circumstances. That is why sensible people get legal advice before they knock up a will and do not go to the local stationary shop and pick up some model form and write in a few assets.

I am sorry, Senator Neal, you were on the phone at the time, but the particular point on which I am interested in knowing your view and the view of the Greens—I think know the view of the Australian Democrats in this matter—is whether the parties should have to have some sort of legal advice before we allow them to register an agreed parenting plan on the basis that it is often the women who are in the least powerful position in these negotiations, the least capable of getting advice, if they want to argue for more time with the kids at Christmas or on holidays or whatever, the least able to pay for that advice and the least likely to have the power to influence the other party and, therefore, most likely to sign an agreement that on reflection and with advice they would not have signed.

The question is: what happens when a woman in such a position, in the least powerful position, has been hoodwinked into signing an agreement that, on reflection or after legal advice, she realises she should not have signed? What cost is she then put to in setting aside those agreements if the other party is not in such a conciliatory position six, nine or 12 months or two years down the track when situations change? For example, when a woman who has been working part time then suddenly works full time, her former spouse might think that changes the situation; or when one party's income changes drastically one way or the other, the other party might think that changes the situation as to what they can do with the children. There is a whole range of things that could change over a period of time and that parties might best be advised about before they sign those agreements.

You have to conclude that there are consequences and that they are expensive for parties to change, but I look forward to the minister's view on that. If he wants to say, `Look there is nothing in this. This is just to make people feel better. We've got a Family Court stamp here. Let's go whack, whack, whack. They can rip it up any time they like and walk away from it any time they like', then people might feel a bit more comfortable. But if that is not the case, then I suspect that Senator Neal and Senator Crowley—all the women on that side—would be particularly concerned at allowing a situation to develop where the least powerful party to the negotiations can enter into a negotiation, come to an agreement, have it registered as though it is a court order and then be faced with quite exceptional expense from that person's point of view in terms of setting it aside. That would defeat one of the purposes that I would have thought women in the Labor Party would be arguing very strongly in favour of.

They are the main issues which we will seek to discuss in the committee stage of this bill. I just want to add that I do understand there are plenty of people in the community who think these changes are inappropriate. Some of them are the people who think anything is inappropriate. As soon as you attach the Family Court to it, they are unhappy with it in any event. Others have different ideas about how we ought to fix the system.

We come to this bill from this perspective: we understand there is no-one who thinks it is working perfectly at the moment—not that I have come across, anyway. While those who are critical of the changes in this bill would say, `They just amount to a lot of schmalzy word changing: custody is custody. Dress it up as something else if you want', I think they are perhaps looking in hope for some improvement. If they are right in their description of these things as being nothing more than schmalzy word changes, I would suggest that, if it at least engenders a different attitude to the parenting of children following separation and if it in any way reduces the animosity and bitterness that are so prevalent at the moment when one party gets custody and the other does not, it will be a good thing. If the changes we make here—to the best of my knowledge I do not think anyone will vote against the bill if they do not get the amendments that they want—make a difference to that over a period of time, it will be a good thing. For that reason, we will be supporting the bill, whether the changes we would like to see made to it are made or not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 [No. 2] and the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995. The Family Law Reform Bill was introduced to implement in part certain recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act 1975 but, in many respects, it goes well beyond the recommendations of that report.

PARA.TAB: One of the key aims of the bill is to facilitate the greater use of mediation, counselling and arbitration in the resolution of family law disputes, both inside and outside the court process. Another major aim of the bill is to restructure part 7, dealing with children, by introducing new concepts and terminology and by emphasising parental responsibilities rather than parental rights. The bill removes references to traditional concepts of custody and access and introduces the new concepts of joint parenting and parental responsibility in providing residence and contact. The government has also introduced the concept of parenting plans, whereby the parents are encouraged to make maintenance provisions regarding the welfare of their children.

Generally, the Australian Democrats welcome this bill as a major step forward in the family law area. However, we have a number of concerns with the bill as it is presently drafted. To begin with, we do not believe that the bill sufficiently ensures that court officials, lawyers, counsellors, mediators, arbitrators and others are sensitive to certain factors in the situation or history of the separating couple when selecting or utilising alternative dispute resolution options, or primary dispute resolution options as they are called in the bill. The Democrats believe that it is completely inappropriate for people to be forced into primary dispute resolution methods where there is a history or risk of domestic violence, child abuse or a serious imbalance in the bargaining power of the parties. As has been said by Senator Vanstone, it is usually the woman who is disadvantaged.

We are therefore proposing to insert guidelines into the bill to make it clear that there are times when primary dispute resolution methods are not a suitable option for the parties. It is important, we believe, to have these guidelines in the bill—in other words, to have the bill transparent as to what is meant and what the options are—and that the pressure on the separating couple is not such that they are pushed into decisions which are possibly not in their best interests. While it might be argued, and I am sure it will be, by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) that elegant drafting does not make provision for repetitious assurances of that type, we believe that we should make every piece of legislation accessible to people who are going to be governed by their provisions. We trust that the government and the opposition will bring a positive feeling to the amendments that I will be moving on behalf of the Democrats.

We are also unhappy with the government's proposal to extend the immunity from suit presently enjoyed by approved mediators and arbitrators to private mediators. The government is proposing to provide immunity to these private mediators, despite there being no comprehensive system of regulation or accreditation in place. Understandably, this proposal received much criticism by witnesses appearing before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. As the Chair of the Family Services Council, Ms Bagshaw, stated in her evidence:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . because it is an absolute privilege, it can be seen as a powerful protection for the mediator and not always in the client's best interests. It should therefore not be lightly given in the absence of satisfactory regulatory framework for private family mediation.

The Democrats will be moving amendments that prevent the extension of the immunity to private mediators and arbitrators, at least until a satisfactory system of accreditation and approval is in place.

PARA.TAB: We are also not satisfied with the objects of part 7 of the bill dealing with children. Presently, this section appears to suggest that parental responsibility is the paramount consideration, but it does not emphasise the need to prevent family violence. We will therefore be moving amendments to confirm the importance of the child's best interests in the part of the bill dealing with children and to make more visible the need to ensure safety from family violence.

One of the most radical aspects of the bill is the removal of references to custody and access, and the introduction of the new terminology which includes residence, contact and special purpose orders. The Democrats understand that this is designed to break the automatic nexus between custody and the responsibility for the daily care and control of the child but believe that it does so in a way that is extremely confusing. We will therefore be introducing amendments that provide a definition of `parental responsibility' which is more descriptive and more easily understood.

We are also seriously concerned at the lack of scrutiny of parenting plans. This is an area that Senator Vanstone adverted to. The Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee specifically recommended that parenting plans should be scrutinised by the court before registration. Unfortunately, however, the government specifically rejected this argument, stating:

SPEECH.PARA: The major thrust of the reforms is to allow parents greater opportunity for deciding what arrangements will be made in respect of their children and/or encouraging greater use of non-litigious dispute resolution mechanisms in settling arrangements where agreement cannot be reached.

There is no problem with that objective and the Democrats wholeheartedly support it. However, there is a problem when this reasoning ignores the fact that five per cent or so of divorces ending up in the Family Court do so because parties are manifestly unable to resolve their differences without some third party assistance.

PARA.TAB: Even where cases do not reach that stage in the court process but are encouraged to reach agreement, we must be certain that they do not reach an agreement that affects their children and how they are being cared for in a trade-off for financial or other advantages in the settlement of property disputes. We must get away from the concept that children are chattels and that parents are able to dispose of them as they wish.

It does remain, in our view, a responsibility for the court to ensure that the welfare of the child is a paramount consideration at all times. The Democrats will therefore be amending these provisions to ensure that parenting plans can be registered by the court if the agreement is signed by both parties, if it is certified by the legal practitioner who has provided advice on the plan and if the court is satisfied that the arrangements set out in the agreement or plan are likely to promote the best interests of the child.

I know that these suggestions have been debated at some length before the committee and that the government has, on numerous occasions, advised that it thinks these provisions would involve the application of resources which are beyond the resources available to the court. I believe that that should not be the paramount consideration. We must first ask the question, `What must we do to ensure the best interests of the child?' The act enjoins us to do that. Then we look at the resources and how best it can be done efficiently and cost effectively. Scrutiny by the court is essential.

I know the other argument is that it is still possible for the court to become involved at the time of one of the parties seeking to enforce an agreement and, in those few cases, that is the time where action should be taken—and that is sufficient. I do not believe that that is a full answer to the concern I am raising because quite clearly many agreements will be concluded and be in force. They will be handled by the parties as an obligation without getting to the point of wanting to go to court to have it enforced and to get the court involved. We must ensure that the court does not renege on its responsibilities as far as the children in a divorce are concerned.

We are also somewhat unhappy with the provisions that threaten criminal sanctions against registrars who intentionally or recklessly disclose information. This provision was strongly criticised by the Chief Justice of the Family Court, Mr Justice Nicholson, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: The penalty is both unnecessary and objectionable. The Court objects strongly to it and points out that such a sanction is found nowhere else in the Family Law Act.

The capacity in which registrars will often deal with this type of information is in the exercise of delegated judicial power and it is particularly inappropriate that those with such power be liable to a criminal sanction arising out [of] its exercise.

The Senate committee also recommended that the provision which allows for the imprisonment of registrars be deleted. We certainly believe that it is an overreaction to a situation that must certainly be looked at.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats will be moving an amendment to the bill to make it mandatory for the Family Court to order separate legal representation for children where a couple with children comes before the court. The discretionary nature of the existing regime and the absence of easy access to legal advice for children do not satisfy either the general principle that all human beings are autonomous individuals, regardless of age, or the provisions of this act that state that the welfare of the child shall be of paramount importance.

The Democrats' amendment is similar to what is the current position in New Zealand where it is mandatory for the court to appoint a barrister or solicitor to represent a child who is not already represented. That has been in force in New Zealand for several years. I have not yet heard that the family court in New Zealand has gone broke or that the exchequer has. The argument that this would be too costly for us to introduce should be rejected. If New Zealand can do it, I really do not see why we cannot have a similar measure.

I would like to recognise the contribution made by some people to the work put into this bill. I must first express appreciation to Judy Harrison of the National Women's Justice Coalition. Over weeks and months she has tirelessly scrutinised the bill and its provisions and has made numerous suggestions for improvements to the bill. In addition, I need to mention a solicitor who has had extensive experience as a community and family lawyer in India, Vandana Herur. She has worked in our office on a voluntary basis on this bill and has with great patience and diligence contributed to the work that has been carried out in my office. She has provided much assistance in helping to develop the Democrats response to the bill. I would like to place on record my appreciation for the considerable work that she has done and that Judy Harrison has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the family law bills that are before the Senate. I would like to make a few preliminary comments about the overall philosophy of the Family Law Act and the Labor government's role in changing family law in Australia. The Labor government has always been at the forefront of law reform, particularly in relation to family law. In 1975, the Labor government introduced the Family law Act after two aborted attempts in 1973 and 1974, and changed the fundamental principles upon which disputes arising from family breakdown are resolved. The act removed the basis of fault in divorce proceedings where often property and children had become the gifts of the victor. Prior to the changes of 1975, children were often very much regarded as property—or at least pseudoproperty.

PARA.TAB: It is an interesting historical quirk that the then Attorney-General, Lionel Murphy, when he introduced the bill, although he envisaged that fault would no longer be applicable in family law proceedings, did not positively state this within the legislation. This caused slight confusion and for a couple of years minor fault factors were taken into account in the Family Court when determining property settlements. It was finally ultimately resolved that fault, except as it directly affected the financial resources of families, would not be taken into account at all.

The act looked towards the future benefit of the family and the individual members. The proceedings were refocused on reaching an arrangement to allow each member of the family to proceed with their lives rather than establishing who had been at fault in the breakdown of the marriage. It is probably an appropriate time to acknowledge the far-sightedness and innovation of those legislators who took steps to change the basis of family law. The old system had operated since civilian courts took over family law from the ecclesiastical courts in 1857.

The amendments before the Senate are aimed at furthering the philosophy of the original bill. There are two major areas of reform: firstly, the orders relating to children; and, secondly, the enhancement of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms in dealing with family law disputes. I was very involved, particularly in the second hearing of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, with this bill. Even though, as Senator Spindler has stated, there were substantial concerns and suggestions as to possible amendments to the bill, the overwhelming majority of witnesses who appeared before us were very much in favour of the thrust of the reform bill and were glad to see it come before this parliament.

I will firstly deal with amendments as they relate to children. Part VII of the act sets out the regime for the making of orders in relation to children. The objects of this section are set out in proposed section 60B. This very much focuses on the needs of the children and their rights and expectations. The principle that a court must regard the best interests of the children as a paramount consideration is clearly stated in section 65, confirming what has been the state of the law for some years.

The main shift in the amending bill is to change the emphasis from parental rights in relation to children of the marriage towards parental responsibility. This is the most valuable part of the bill. It confronts an emphasis that I do not believe has been in the interests of children and, ultimately, of parents.

It has been argued that the demise of fault provisions as a basis for divorce has called parties to in some cases seek another outlet to assert who carries the blame for the family breakdown. This may be seen through the contest involving property division and sometimes, unfortunately, who is `victorious'—I use that term very guardedly—in being awarded custody of the children. Section 61 of the act clearly states the responsibility of a parent towards the child, notwithstanding a change in their circumstances or a change to the family with regard to the relationship between the parents. The bill carries further this principle by altering the terminology as it relates to parents and their children.

The concepts of custody and access are abandoned. The court may make orders in four ways. The first is called residence orders. In some regards, they are similar to custody orders but do not go so far. They do not deal with the complete care and control of the child. The second type of order is the contact order, which in some parts is similar to what is now known as access orders. Child maintenance orders are fairly self-explanatory.

The final creature, the special purpose order, is a completely new creature of this legislation. It allows a flexibility that was not provided before. It abandons the situation where one parent has almost total care and control of the child and the other parent is involved only briefly through access visits and the payment of maintenance. It straitjacketed people in the past into trying to get their family to fit into a largely uniform and predetermined regime which was often unsatisfactory for all parties concerned, particularly the children. This terminology recognises the unique nature of each child and family and encourages the parties to make individual orders crafted particularly for their circumstances.

This division also provides for the registration of parenting plans. It in fact encourages them. Parents can sit down together and work out what best suits them and their children rather than there being a situation where standard custody is granted to one parent and access is granted every second weekend to the other, which is presently commonplace. The plans can provide, for example—these are only examples—for a child to stay three days at one house and four at another or spend one year at one parent's home and alternate years at the other's. It can provide for religious or cultural instruction that the child is to receive, the type of diet that should be provided, the type and level of education, the relationship with step-parents and siblings and the type of discipline applied to the child. Alternatively, it can be just a one-line, wide open and completely flexible statement about the parents' philosophy. The details can be left to be worked out as the parents see fit from day to day. The only restriction is the overriding principle that the children's interests be paramount.

The bill also particularly deals with contact orders in a situation of domestic violence. The bill clearly directs that the court must not make contact orders that are inconsistent with apprehended domestic violence orders that have been made in the state courts. Further, the orders they make in relation to children should not expose parties to a risk of domestic violence.

There was some suggestion by Senator Vanstone in her comments as they related to children and parenting orders that somehow the motivation for this bill was to ensure that lawyers and, in particular, family lawyers were removed from the process. It certainly is not my intention and I do not believe the intention of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) or the government to take steps to ensure that family lawyers are not involved. In my view, at the risk of being self-serving with regard to my former career, it is not a major difficulty in ensuring that parents can work out arrangements that are best suited to them and their children.

The object of these sort of orders is to allow them the flexibility to do what suits them, not to ensure that lawyers are not trying to rip them off or spend more time on continuing litigation when it is unnecessary. This bill is trying to say that parents are responsible to their children. They do not have rights in relation to the children. The rights are all with the children. They must work out with each other where they can what is in their best interest. They must recognise that this will be an ongoing regime that will continue. They have to work with each other.

The trouble with proceedings in court is that, as well as being expensive and inconvenient for the parties involved, the delicate and tentative relationship that often exists between parents after a family breakdown and which must continue for the ongoing care of the children is further damaged. In my view, the aspects of the bill that deal with children are particularly directed at preserving that relationship to the extent that that is possible and not to further erode it with ugly court room scenes, confrontation and further unpleasantness between the parties. In my view, this is the essential objective of this aspect of the bill and the latter aspects, which I will go on to deal with. I do not believe the motivation is to ensure that families in a breakdown situation are not ripped off by greedy and, as it might be put, dishonourable members of the legal profession.

I would also like to deal with counselling and mediation, which are set out in parts II, III and IIIA of the bill. It is a fairly well-known fact that 95 per cent of matters in the Family Court are resolved before the hearing. This is a very laudable figure. It shows that parties in many cases are very keen to ensure that they resolve their disputes before they go to a hearing.

Parties often do not face up to the necessity to resolve their dispute until they come face to face at the court on the first return date and have the opportunity to face each other, discuss the issues between them and attempt to resolve them. The big advantage of mediation as a first point of dispute resolution is that, before they take the step of commencing proceedings and having a first return and all the various other steps involved before hearing, they get an opportunity to talk to each other in a fairly relaxed atmosphere with a trained third party whose attitude is conducive to a resolution to try to come to what is very popularly described these days as a win-win situation.

They can put aside the set views that the court may have that do not suit either party in regard to children. They can reach decisions that they are quite happy with and can live with. It may not be the absolutely best solution for either one of them. As a group, they are happier than they would have been, potentially, if the matter had gone to court.

The emphasis that this bill places on mediation is a good thing, despite the potential loss of business in terms of face-to-face litigation for family lawyers. It is very clear that the majority of the profession are very supportive of mediation. Prior to this bill, there had been a gradual increase in the utilisation of informal mediation throughout the profession. The broad scope of views expressed to me within both the court and the profession saw the tendency for mediation as something that could enhance the role of lawyers in that they are left to advise and, if necessary, to litigate in those matters that are most entrenched and are not suited to mediation.

I agree with some of the concerns expressed by Senator Spindler in relation to mediation in situations where domestic violence has played a role. Where my view differs is that I feel the bill before the house today allows scope and flexibility so that mediation is not persisted with or is not forced where the circumstance is not appropriate. Very clearly, where there is an existing violent domestic situation or there has been a relationship where domestic violence was a component and one party used their greater power in the relationship to push around the other, mediation is not appropriate and the mediator would assess that and clearly state that before the matter is proceeded with.

There are other situations in which mediation may not be applicable. Those matters are assessed by the mediator. There is certainly not going to be a situation where people, in circumstances that are not appropriate, are forced against their will to deal with another party if that is going to cause them difficulty or distress.

I have been somewhat disappointed by the general response of the opposition, which as usual have taken a fairly negative role in this debate. Both Mr Andrews in the House of Representatives and Senator Vanstone in this house have not opposed this bill, but they have not supported it. That is very sad, in light of the general community support for the principles set out in this bill. I suppose it is not inconsistent with their general view at the moment, which is that their best option is to put forward no position and no policy. I hope that, despite that, further speakers will see fit to support the bill. I commend it to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill was introduced into the Senate on 28 November last year and was referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on that date. As a result of this and another exposure bill, that committee tabled a first report on 6 March this year, and a second one on 21 June.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Family Law Act 1975 as a first stage in implementing the government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. The main areas it seeks to amend are, firstly, dispute resolution through mediation and provisions relating to what is traditionally known as custody and access of children.

At the outset I commend to the Senate the two reports I mentioned by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. I would have thought that the work done there by senators from the government, Senator Spindler from the Australian Democrats and senators from the coalition was most fruitful and constructive and that there was not any negativity, as previously mentioned, in relation to the approach taken by those senators in examining this bill.

The bill, as I stated earlier, deals with counselling and mediation. The stated aims of the amendments are, firstly, to facilitate greater use of mediation, counselling and arbitration in the resolution of family law disputes, both within the court and in approved organisations in the community. The second aim of these amendments is to provide for an approval mechanism for community based counselling and mediation organisations to become approved mediation and/or counselling organisations under the Family Law Act.

The third aspect is to expand the opportunity for approved organisations to undertake mediation and counselling that arises under the Family Law Act. The fourth intended aim of these amendments is to extend the immunity provisions that presently exist from court based personnel to approved mediators. I add that there is the further intention of extending the secrecy and admission provisions that presently exist from court based personnel to approved community mediators and counsellors.

The coalition does not oppose these amendments as they reflect the trend away from litigation and one which progresses towards resolution through negotiation. I would point to the figures which display this in the Family Court in particular. The Family Court, I would suggest, has been very successful in the area of mediation, with some 96.3 per cent of all disputes being settled prior to trial.

I point to the position in my home state of Western Australia. The Family Court there in the late 1970s and early 1980s made much use of the pre-trial conference, which was an effective tool in settling matters before they went to court. I believe that has caught on throughout Australia. In the civil jurisdiction you see the courts making much use of the pre-trial procedure. I believe that these amendments are an extension of that and are quite useful in sorting out matters and in avoiding matters going to court that otherwise should not go to court.

The bill also imposes an obligation on the court and legal practitioners to consider whether or not to advise the parties concerned about primary dispute mechanisms. It also accommodates an increase in the demand for counselling services that would arise out of this. The bill sets out a counselling and mediation regime and the organisations that would become involved.

One of the concerns that were raised during the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee's hearing was that there was nothing to indicate that there would be any regulation as to minimum standards for qualifications training and ongoing professional development in this regard. Added to this concern was the fact that the immunity currently given to court based personnel would extend to the private mediators.

In response to that the government, I understand, has accepted this recommendation and stated that the development of this would occur through broadly based consultations. I hope that these rules and regulations which deal with the supervision of the qualifications of counsellors and the like are comprehensive. I think this is essential. If you are to have effective mediation counselling, you must provide your counsellors and mediators with sufficient training and qualification.

The other aspect of this bill which is most important deals with children. In relation to this aspect the bill proposes a fundamental change in philosophy. Two reports on these issues have been instrumental in relation to these changes. The first of these was the Patterns of parenting after separation report by the Family Law Council, and there was an evaluation taken out in relation to the United Kingdom Children's Act 1989. There was a report on this in 1994 to the Attorney-General by way of letter of advice.

In both reports the Family Law Council concluded that cooperative parenting after separation was both beneficial and desirable for the welfare of the child and would be facilitated if the language of family law did not carry overtones of ownership—and previous speakers have touched on this. The term `custody' implies what one might look upon as an aspect of ownership. One has custody of documents or chattels. I think it is an unfortunate term when looking at children.

When I look back on my involvement with family law as a private practitioner, I certainly did discover that with some of my clients and the people I dealt with there was an aspect of ownership and that the person who got custody won. There was an aspect of there being a winner and a loser. That was an unfortunate aspect of this term. Similarly with the term `access', you have access to land or access to a right of way. Again that has connotations of proprietary aspects. I think the new terms or concepts of parental responsibility and parenting plans are, indeed, a step forward.

Instead of parents obtaining an order for custody or access, they will now obtain residence and contact orders. This is to allow day-to-day care and the long-term care of the child to be made separately and to emphasise the joint responsibilities of parents in relation to the provision of residence and contact. I think it is most important that the message be got across to parents that there is a joint responsibility in the future welfare of the children after a separation has occurred.

There was some concern raised at the public hearings of the legal and constitutional committee regarding this change in terminology. These concerns were based on the lack of definition of the new terms, and the misunderstandings which might follow. For my part, I would agree that any change in terminology goes through a transitional period where people have to adapt to the change, but one thing I find quite agreeable in relation to terms such as `parental responsibility' and `parental plans' is that you are involving plain English. Anyone who came to this new legislation without any prior knowledge would understand what those terms mean. I do not think there will be much problem in relation to those terms. I think the average man and woman in the street would readily understand them.

One thing which did arise was the concern of the Law Council of Australia about the lack of scrutiny in consent orders and parenting plans that would be presented to the Family Court. As such, the committee expressed some concern in relation to this. Certainly in relation to property, there are certain requirements that have to be met—maintenance and the various agreements that are provided for—and you find that the court has some aspect of inquiry when one looks at deeds of agreement in relation to property. I would have thought that in relation to children this ability should be available to the court where there is an agreement put to the court.

One could certainly say that the parents know what is best for the children. But after there has been a separation, I think there is some role for the court to play in that regard, because at that stage perhaps the parents are not working in conjunction with each other and may well be agreeing to things for ulterior motives.

With respect to the various orders that can be made, I have touched on residence orders, which deal with where the child will live; contact orders, which deal with contact between the child and another person; but there are also child maintenance orders and special purpose orders which can be made. You could have a variety of aspects being dealt with in these four separate areas. I think that flexibility is quite important.

One matter which did arise during the hearings was that presented by the grandparents action group. In this regard I refer to the grandparents action group of Western Australia, which made detailed representations to me. I thought these representations entailed a good deal of merit. Basically, the gist of what this group stated was that section 69C of the act mentions those people who can initiate orders or apply for orders and that grandparents were left out. Grandparents were really left in that class of other people.

In looking at the bill I have before me, I note that grandparents are still not yet included, although I understood the government was minded to accede to this concern and allow provisions specifically for grandparents. From my experience in family law, where you had a break-up between husband and wife, the grandparents played a key role generally in the care of the child.

I think there would be no harm done in the bill referring specifically to grandparents, so that your primary application would come from the parents of the child and then, if you had to have a pecking order, you would consider the grandparents next and then other people such as relations or perhaps a de facto spouse. But I do think it is important that grandparents be given that recognition.

There are a couple of other matters I will touch on briefly. Firstly, the potential criminal sanction in relation to Family Court registrars mentioned in section 67P. The committee expressed concern about this. I have the gravest of concerns about this provision. Indeed, His Honour Mr Justice Nicholson, who appeared before the committee, stated in relation to this provision, `The penalty is both unnecessary and objectionable. The court objects strongly to it and points out that such a sanction is found nowhere else in the Family Law Act.' I would endorse those comments. I believe it really is an over-reaction to a situation which does not require this sort of action. It really does set a precedent which is regrettable.

Another aspect I would touch on is section 68T(5), which the committee expressed some concern about. The committee stated in recommendation 2 in its report in March this year that the 21 days now provided for in the bill as the period during which a person is prevented from appealing against the decision of a magistrate's court to interfere with a contact order made by the Family Court should be reduced to three days. This was basically saying that, if you appealed a contact order which prohibited you from having access, you could be denied access for up to 21 days because of the waiting period you had to endure.

The committee thought that there should be available to the person concerned a much shorter period under which to file an application or an appeal. I think that is a very important point, and one which could result in furthering animosity between parties where one party was stopped by a contact order from having access and then had to wait 21 days within which the appeal could be heard.

I think that is a very important aspect. As I understand it, the government has not taken this on board. I hope I am wrong in that regard. But if I am not, it is regrettable that the government has not taken that aspect on board. I certainly think that a lot of people in Australia with access orders—as they are currently known—made in favour of them would be apprehensive about this sort of amendment.

Another aspect touched on in the committee's report dealt with the question of domestic violence. The committee in its report looked at the question of domestic violence and it recommended that section 68K be redrafted to express in positive terms that the Family Court when making an order must have regard to safeguards in order to avoid exposure to family violence. This is again another thoroughly worthwhile amendment.

I commend the two reports on these bills of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. Whilst I welcome the various provisions that I have touched on in the Family Law Reform Bill, I also express the concerns which have been expressed by the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. I think this is one of the greatest amendments to the Family Law Act 1975 since the act's inception in that year, and I believe that some review and scrutiny of how these amendments progress is essential. Hopefully, the government will be responsive to any feedback in relation to the operation of these all-encompassing amendments, but that is something that we will have to deal with in the future if and when it arises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with amendments to the Family Law Act through the Family Law Reform Bill and the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill. This act probably affects more Australians than any other act, except the tax act. That is not an original comment of mine, but we need to be reminded, every now and again, that these are bills of such magnitude.

PARA.TAB: In 1994, 48,256 divorces were granted in Australia. We have been proceeding at about that rate for some considerable time. That gives an indication of the extent to which people are involved in this area. One of the significant differences between this act and the tax act is that the Family Law Act is a far more emotionally charged area of activity, I believe, so we need to look at it from the point of view of all parties involved in it.

The report that these bills in part respond to was tabled in November 1992 and was titled The Family Law Act 1975: aspects of its operation and interpretation. The committee report contained 120 recommendations. One of the recommendations was that the committee itself should go ahead and analyse, look at and examine the Child Support Agency because, during the time of the hearing of the first inquiry, the question of the Child Support Agency came up to such an extent that we felt we had to recommend a review of that as well. That review has also been done.

It is a matter of great disappointment to me that the government for some reason has shelved dealing with the significant issues under the Child Support Agency act. I believe that the agency itself has taken note of the recommendations that we made with respect to its operations. I believe the agency has made many changes and is working diligently and conscientiously towards making its aspect of it function properly, but the government seems to have washed its hands of dealing with the significant issues relating to the formula which we dealt with. The time for the government to have responded is now long overdue; they have obviously put it off hoping to hide behind it before the next election in that they have said that they will not respond until next year. They cannot be condemned strongly enough, I believe, for ignoring that very significant aspect. It is what is driving so much of the anguish and despair that exists in our community at the present time.
The act itself that we are reviewing is 20 years old, and it has been referred to quite extensively recently in the media. An article in the Sunday Telegraph of 1 October started off by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: "Twenty years after the introduction of the Family Law Act senior court officials have declared its original goal `impossible' to fulfil. Former Attorney-General Lionel Murphy's dream of a `friendly family court' which would end the bitterness of marital breakdowns was beyond any human institution", court officials have said.

And that of course is the fact. I think this is where people were misled in the first instance, by thinking that one could turn this area of law and this area of human activity into a friendly family court.

PARA.TAB: I think it might have been better had those who put this act together in 1975 been more realistic about what could have been achieved rather than proceeding with this concept of the friendly Family Court and producing a situation where people expected things to be so much better. They have not been. The reason why they have not been better is that you cannot change human nature. You cannot take out of divorce the human hurt that so often flows from it. You cannot take out the shattered dreams that have resulted from the breakdown of the marriage. You cannot take away the aspirations of a couple in love proceeding to marriage in the first place. I think that point was missed, and it is a great pity that it was missed because it might have been easier otherwise.

The Family Law Act, though reprinted, is a pretty formidable document. It could not by any stretch of the imagination be described as a friendly act to deal with. Section 38 has 55 little subsections and bits to it. You need someone who is fairly competent to help you find your way around that. Section 66 starts on page 82 and finishes on page 100 with 31 principal clauses containing up to 11 subclauses. It concludes with 66ZE(1) and (2). I mention that merely to point out that it is not a simple document that anyone can just pick up, thumb through, and find out what will happen to them in the event that their marriage has failed. There are many issues in the act that we could discuss today.

I believe that the 1975 act was flawed for missing the point of what would happen afterwards. You could take the concept of fault out of the law, certainly, but you could not take it out of the hearts and minds of the people who feel aggrieved by the way they have been treated by someone else in this jurisdiction. This is the second major inquiry by the parliament into the Family Law Act, and there is no doubt that there will be more inquiries in time to come. It is a very emotional area.

The amendments that we have before us at the present time deal with some of the significant issues contained in the report relating to counselling and mediation. They are most welcome. They are important. They will need to be constantly reviewed, and managed in a way that they can be as meaningful as possible to the people who come before the court and whose marriages have failed. We need to go through the grieving process, in particular, and solve the problems of getting on with life—especially for the children of the former marriage—with as few traumas from the breakdown as possible.

One of the things in the act that I particularly welcome, and that I would have liked to have been a recommendation in the original report, relates to the use of the word `custody'. I was not able to persuade the committee at the time that we should recommend getting rid of that word. I suppose you can completely get rid of it. When two people have a child, that child is in the custody of both of them forever and no-one can change that. Until we shift attitudes on the definition of that word we will continue to have problems in this area. It might take a decade for it to work its way out of the system.

`Custody' is an extremely emotive word. This country was started by many of the first settlers coming here in custody. `Custody' tends to bring up images of being in the hands of the police at a police station. `Custody' in this area tends to mean owning the child: `He won't have custody of my children' or `I won't let her have custody of my children.' The word is spat out with such venom. It means ownership, and ownership is the last thing that any parent actually has of their child. The High Court in Marian's case has been quoted often enough. The principle of law is that parental rights are derived from parental duty and exist only so long as they are needed for the protection of the person and the property of the child. In my view, the word `custody' has to be eliminated—and probably `guardianship' as well because the misunderstandings as to what it means are fairly great.

Having given birth to a child, the question of joint custody exists forever and nobody changes it. That is what I would hope. The court, if it is required to make a determination about what happens to the children of the marriage, will make a whole range of orders covering such things as where the children will live and which parent will make decisions about the children's health, welfare and education and all the other things that need to be determined. It may well be that a court will make an order that one parent has no contact with the children. The word `custody' would not be used here.

In that way, the concept of ownership can be eliminated. Honourable senators might think that is playing with words. However, my experience in this area indicates that it is a lot more than playing with words: it has real significance. Maintenance for the children these days is normally determined under the Child Support Agency. If it is a matter for the court it will be spelt out. I believe that in time we will get rid of the concept of ownership of children. The children may live principally with the mother and visit the father at certain times and live with him. It could spell out addresses and a lot of other things.

I think we would then be moving in a direction which would make a difference. In the future, as in the past, most of the orders with respect to children will be consent orders whereby the parents put down the arrangements that they want the court to take into account in determining whether or not proper arrangements have been made for the welfare of the children of the marriage. They could be expansive or less expansive, depending on the circumstances. But if the court itself has to determine what will happen with the children, and there is a contested hearing, the word `custody' should not be used in the orders that are finally presented to the parties. I believe that in time we would be making a difference.

I welcome the governments's attitude to this. The government did what the report suggested: it took further evidence and advice about it. I see it as a big plus. Associated with that are the recommendations in relation to parenting plans. I do not believe that the court should be involved in inspecting every parenting arrangement that comes before it. I think that is far too intrusive. It assumes that most parents cannot put together a reasonable package for the welfare of their children. That is not the case. The number of cases actually contested is quite small.

There is another grey area where people agreed to things because they believed that they would not win if they went to court or that it would cost too much money. I accept that. But people do work out the arrangements that they can put together. They may not be entirely happy with them, but at least they have put the arrangements together themselves. I totally reject the intrusive `Big Brother knows best' attitude of suggesting that parenting plans should be investigated and looked at by the court and not giving some credit to the parents for being able to put the package together.

I want to deal with grandparents and a few other issues arising from this legislation. It is not possible to speak to everything in the 20 minutes allowed. I seek leave to continue my remarks later and proceed with other aspects of the amendments when the matter comes on again.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
